HEADLINE: Senate Budget Shows Signs Of G.O.P. Strain With Bush

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG; Richard W. Stevenson contributed reporting for this article.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18 

 BODY:
In its last-minute flurry of votes before approving a budget Thursday night, the Senate added $5.4 billion in education spending for 2006 -- just one more sign, members of both parties said on Friday, that President Bush could not get all he wanted on Capitol Hill despite the strengthened Republican majority.
 Mr. Bush had sought to impose strict spending restraints on lawmakers, and the weeklong budget debate was a test of his strength on Capitol Hill. The $2.57 trillion Senate budget resolution, which differs sharply from the budget passed by the House, gave Mr. Bush much of what he asked for: tax cut extensions, a provision allowing oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, cuts in farm subsidies and reductions in the growth of some entitlement programs. 
 But on some key votes, enough Senate Republicans joined Democrats to defy the president. In a blow to Mr. Bush, the Senate stripped from the budget all $14 billion in proposed spending cuts in Medicaid. Senators also restored $2 billion in cuts to a popular urban renewal program and approved the extra money for education, to help middle-class families pay for college.
 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who offered the education amendment, said the vote, coupled with the Senate's decision on Medicaid, indicated that Republicans were uneasy about cutting social programs too deeply.
 ''On issues in education and health and investment, there is a concern that the administration is going too far,'' Mr. Kennedy said. 
 But a senior administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the White House was pleased over all. In a statement released Thursday night, President Bush praised the House's budget, which closely resembles his own. On Friday, the administration official said that in the Senate, ''there were some good developments, the most important being that they passed the budget resolution.''
 This official added: ''We've demonstrated that we have the votes or are within a couple of votes of what we need. If you have only one or two votes to make up, that's not a bad place to be.''
 The competing budgets passed by the House and Senate raised questions about whether the two versions could be reconciled into one document that both chambers would approve. In an interview Friday, Senator Judd Gregg, the New Hampshire Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee, seemed reluctant to make any predictions.
 ''Clearly, there's some fairly significant differences to resolve,'' Mr. Gregg said, ''but we're all on the same team, hopefully.''
 The budget resolution sets tax and spending guidelines, but Congress has been unable to pass a budget for two of the last three years. This year, passing one is essential for the Republican leadership on Capitol Hill. With the federal deficit at a record high, President Bush and Republicans have campaigned on a theme of fiscal responsibility, and failure to pass a budget resolution would be an embarrassment to the White House and Congress.
 At the same time, there will be real consequences for the Republican agenda. The budget provides procedural protections that enable lawmakers to adopt the tax-cut extensions, reduce entitlement spending and open the Arctic refuge to oil drilling without the threat of a filibuster in the Senate. If the budget does not pass, those measures are all but doomed.
 Finally, the budget sets limits on spending that cannot be exceeded without a 60-vote majority in the Senate. The last time Congress passed a budget, for 2004, it included caps for two years. Now the caps are about to expire; the 2006 budget will renew them for three years.
 One of the debate's most surprising twists came when the Senate, by a vote of 55 to 45, approved $64 billion in added tax cuts, a measure intended to repeal a 1993 law taxing 85 percent of Social Security benefits for individuals who earn more than $34,000 and couples earning more than $44,000. Afterward, some senators seemed confused about what they had voted on.
 Mr. Gregg said the repeal of the Social Security tax was not likely to survive the House-Senate conference. He said senators regarded it as ''a message amendment,'' intended to signal that they oppose the tax. 
 Senator Norm Coleman of Minnesota was among the Republicans supporting Democrats on some issues. He backed Mr. Kennedy's education amendment, led the effort to restore urban development money and opposed drilling in the refuge. But he voted for the final budget.
 ''In the end,'' Mr. Coleman said, ''the most important vote is the last vote.''

HEADLINE: Russian and European Leaders Discover Common Ground on Lebanon and Iran

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH

DATELINE: PARIS, March 18 

 BODY:
The leaders of France, Germany, Russia and Spain gathered for an informal meeting here on Friday and issued a joint statement urging Syria to withdraw troops and security services from Lebanon. They also said they were united in their desire to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons. 
 The meeting, preceded by a lunch between President Jacques Chirac of France and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, was meant partly to bolster Russian-European Union relations and overcome growing unease with Mr. Putin's increasingly authoritarian governance. Recent restrictions on the Russian news media and increasing economic recentralization, in particular, have raised concerns in Europe. 
 The United States has already made its concerns known. At a meeting between the Russian leader and President Bush last month in Bratislava, Slovakia, Mr. Bush reportedly rebuked Mr. Putin behind closed doors and then gently chided him in public.
 But the dynamics are somewhat different in Europe: France, Germany and Spain appear more willing to overlook Russia's blemishes in favor of stronger relations that might serve to strengthen their hand with the United States later on. 
 Though there is growing American unease with Russia over Iran, which is developing a nuclear power capability with Russian help, no friction was apparent on Friday. 
 ''There's no contradiction between the Russian position and the position that England, Germany and France are trying to negotiate,'' Mr. Chirac said at a news conference after the meeting. France and Germany, together with Britain and the European Union, are trying to dissuade Iran from pursuing technology that would make it capable of building nuclear weapons. 
 Russia has signed an agreement to supply Iran with low-enriched uranium for its reactors that requires Iran to return all of the spent fuel, preventing them from enriching it to weapons grade or reprocessing it to recover weapons-grade plutonium. 
 The leaders at the meeting on Friday also found common ground on lifting the European Union embargo on arms sales to China, a move that the United States strongly opposes. Russia is China's main arms supplier, and Mr. Putin said that while he would not welcome the competition, he said he was sure Russia and Europe could work together in the Chinese arms market. 
 Mr. Chirac's lunch with Mr. Putin, without support staff or note-takers, according to the Elysee Palace press office, was the venue for Mr. Chirac to be most frank about European apprehensions. But whatever was said was left discreetly behind closed doors. ''We evoked all of the problems that are the order of the day between our two countries,'' was all Mr. Chirac would said say about the meeting. 
 Mr. Putin's meeting with Mr. Chirac, Prime Minister Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero of Spain and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany was as much one of reassurance that he was welcome in Europe than of communicating concern. In a sign that Russia is still in the club, Mr. Chirac took Mr. Putin on a tour of the heart of French air defenses 20 miles northwest of Paris. The tour was in reciprocation for an April 2004 visit to Russia's Krasnoznamensk space flight control center.
 Mr. Putin also said he would work for stability in Ukraine, where Moscow's initial opposition to the election of Viktor A. Yushchenko as president brought international criticism. He will visit the country on Saturday for the first time since Mr. Yushchenko came to power.

PERSON: Sol Myron Linowitz

HEADLINE: Sol M. Linowitz Dies at 91; Businessman and Diplomat

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS

 BODY:
Sol M. Linowitz, a confidant of Democratic presidents who became renowned for his achievements in each of his three careers -- lawyer, businessman and diplomat -- died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 91. 
 His death was reported by his family.
 A courtly and graceful figure on the Washington scene for nearly four decades, Mr. Linowitz was one of the handful of people who truly fit the description ''wise man,'' applied to those in Washington whose counsel was regularly sought by presidents, senators and others in power. Among the complex jobs he filled were negotiator for the Panama Canal treaties and special presidential envoy for the Middle East. 
 When he was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1998, President Bill Clinton told the White House audience that getting ''advice from Sol Linowitz on international diplomacy is like getting trumpet lessons from the angel Gabriel.'' 
 As a young lawyer and businessman he achieved acclaim as a principal developer of the Xerox Corporation and he became its chairman. His first call from the White House seeking advice came from President John F. Kennedy. Senator Robert F. Kennedy also consulted Mr. Linowitz and once urged him to run for governor of New York. Mr. Linowitz later said that he did not like the idea of asking people to vote for him, especially since he had no great quarrel with the state's leadership under the incumbent Republican he would have to challenge, Nelson A. Rockefeller. 
 Mr. Linowitz over the years became a trusted counsel to Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson and Jimmy Carter before he served in that role for Mr. Clinton. Although most of his years in Washington were as a private lawyer, he was often called upon to take on delicate diplomatic tasks.
 He served in the government as a lawyer in the Office of Price Administration during World War II, but he was first lured to a senior policy post by President Johnson who made him the United States representative to the Organization of American States, the international organization that was the principal conclave for Washington to deal with Latin America. 
 For Mr. Linowitz, his term at the O.A.S. from 1966 to 1969 was the beginning of an involvement for the remainder of his life with the region's political and economic issues and its relations with the United States.
 His autobiography, ''The Making of a Public Man'' (Little Brown, 1985), recounted several anecdotes of President Johnson at his cajoling and bullying best. He noted that when Mr. Johnson obliquely criticized him in front of several cabinet members early in his tenure, he sought a private conversation in which he told the president that he would resign if that happened again.
 Mr. Linowitz wrote that he had determined that the best way to do his government job was to always believe and let others know that he could ''pick up his marbles and go home.''
 He wrote that President Johnson replied: ''Hell, boy, you're getting upset over nothing.'' After that the president was generally solicitous of him, except for one occasion when Mr. Linowitz told him he thought the Vietnam War was going badly and Mr. Johnson snapped, ''I don't want you to talk to me about that subject.''
 In 1977, President Carter asked Mr. Linowitz to be one of the two negotiators for the Panama Canal treaties with Ellsworth Bunker, who had been ambassador to Vietnam. It was a long political fight and one that earned Mr. Linowitz the unending enmity of many conservatives, notably Jesse Helms, then a Republican senator from North Carolina who led the opposition to turning the canal back to Panama.
 Once driving down Constitution Avenue, Mr. Linowitz saw himself hanging in effigy as part of a protest by conservative opponents of the treaty. He said that to get through what was a particularly painful time he lived by a phrase from ''The Aeneid'' by Virgil, translated as: ''One day it will please us to remember even this.''
 In 1979 he was named special ambassador to the Middle East by President Carter and found himself embroiled in the complex issues, notably Palestinian autonomy, that followed the Camp David peace accords. When he was asked to take the job, he told President Carter that he was uncertain if his heavy involvement in Jewish organizations and causes would be an obstacle. 
 He noted that his predecessors in the position, Robert S. Strauss and Henry A. Kissinger, were Jewish but were more secular. His concerns were largely allayed when he learned that one of his biggest supporters was Ashfraf Gorbal, Egypt's ambassador to Washington. 
 As a lawyer in Rochester, he became friends with Joe Wilson, who owned the Haloid Corporation and who had come across a promising invention called electrophotography. Within a dozen years, they had built a company they called Xerox that changed the way the world did business. 
 The inventor Chester F. Carlson had devised a way to copy documents, and by 1956, Mr. Linowitz, as vice president in charge of patents, obtained all rights to the Carlson invention. 
 Mr. Linowitz was named Xerox's chairman in 1960 and the next year the company's revenue surged to $176 million. By the time he resigned in 1966 to accept President Johnson's ambassadorial appointment, the corporation's annual operating revenue had reached half a billion dollars.
 Mr. Linowitz was a partner in the Coudert Brothers international law firm from 1969 until his retirement in 1994. Over the years, he become something of a preacher to lawyers. In speeches, and eventually a book, he expressed considerable dismay about what he said were the changing mores in the legal profession. His recommendations included fundamental changes in legal education, including greater emphasis on ethics and humanities, some of which were adopted at his own alma mater, Cornell Law School, where he was a trustee.
 He also took an interest in the nation's cities, serving as president of the National Urban League. 
 Mr. Linowitz is survived by his wife, Toni, and by four daughters: June Linowitz of Bethesda, Md.; Anne Mozersky of Ottawa; Jan Linowitz of Wynnewood, Pa.; and Roni Jolles of Great Falls, Va.; and eight grandchildren. Other survivors are three brothers, R. Robert Linowes and David S. Linowes, both of Chevy Chase, Md., and Harry M. Linowes of Bethesda.
 Sol Myron Linowitz was born Dec. 7, 1913, in Trenton to immigrants from Russia. His father was a wholesale fruit merchant who suffered badly in the Depression and never fully recovered. Mr. Linowitz went to Hamilton College, in upstate New York, one of only a handful of Jews at the small liberal arts college. He said that forced him to look more closely at his religious heritage. 
 While at Hamilton, he appeared in college productions and was urged to take up the stage professionally by Alexander Woolcott, then the college's drama director. He helped meet his expenses by playing violin in the Utica Symphony Orchestra and summer dance bands.
 As part of his scholarship he was given a job to read to Elihu Root, the former secretary of state and an alumnus of Hamilton, who had chosen to spend his final years at the college. Root interrupted the reading once to ask what Mr. Linowitz would do when he graduated. Mr. Linowitz said he was considering being either a lawyer or a rabbi.
 ''Become a lawyer,'' Mr. Linowitz said he was told. ''I have found that a lawyer needs twice as much religion as a minister or rabbi.''


CORRECTION-DATE: March 31, 2005

 CORRECTION:
An obituary of the businessman and diplomat Sol M. Linowitz on March 19 misspelled the surname of a critic and essayist who was an alumnus of Mr. Linowitz's alma mater, Hamilton College, and misstated the man's postgraduate affiliation with it. The alumnus was Alexander Woollcott, not Woolcott. He was visiting the campus when he saw Mr. Linowitz in a student production and urged him to take up the stage professionally; he was not the director of the school's drama program.

HEADLINE: Europe and U.S. Still Deadlocked On Jet Subsidies

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18 

 BODY:
Government officials said on Friday evening that talks with the European Union had broken down over how to control billions of dollars in subsidies that each accuses the other of giving to its biggest civilian aircraft maker. 
 With three weeks left to negotiate an agreement, Robert B. Zoellick, the deputy secretary of state, said through a spokesman that Washington no longer believed that Europe wanted to give up its subsidies to Airbus, which competes with Boeing in supplying most of the world's large commercial jetliners. 
 ''Despite our best efforts, it is clear that the European Union is unwilling to eliminate launch-aid subsidies,'' Mr. Zoellick said in a statement. Until recently, Mr. Zoellick was the United States trade representative and he has continued to play the lead role in negotiating the issue. 
 The talks broke down, according to the spokesman, during a telephone conversation late Friday afternoon between Mr. Zoellick and Peter Mandelson, the top European trade minister.
 But Anthony Gooch, a spokesman for the European Union in Washington, said that Mr. Mandelson was ''completely surprised that such a statement should be given to the press.''
 ''There are clearly difficult issues at stake,'' Mr. Gooch said, but Mr. Mandelson ''doesn't recognize the portrayal of the state of play as offered by the U.S. side.''
 ''If Mr. Zoellick is announcing that the negotiations are at an end, Mr. Mandelson has not been informed of this development.'' 
 In his statement, Mr. Zoellick stopped short of breaking off talks but said that if the European Union ''either breaks or refuses to extend the terms of the Jan. 11 agreement we will return to litigation.''
 This would mean Europe would have to agree to indefinite suspension of all subsidies until an agreement is reached, even if the negotiations go past the self-imposed April 11 deadline for reaching a deal.
 The April 11 deadline is important because the United States is concerned that Europe will give new subsidies, or launch aid, to the A350, a midsize airplane that Airbus is designing to compete directly with Boeing's new 7E7 Dreamliner airplane. Early this year, the United States and the European Union were poised to file formal complaints against each other at the World Trade Organization over government support given to Boeing and Airbus. But in advance of President Bush's trip to Europe the sides agreed to engage in private negotiations to try to resolve the issue. 
 If the breakdown continues and the two sides end up arguing before the W.T.O., it will be the biggest case ever heard by the group's dispute settlement arm and could lead to a ruling that might seriously damage the profitability of an important industry for both continents. 
 In disclosing the breakdown, the Bush administration accused Brussels of changing the terms of the negotiations. Instead of discussing the subsidies alone, the administration said, Europe also insisted on discussing the immediate elimination of tax cuts for American exporters, including Boeing, that were declared illegal by the W.T.O. 
 The Europeans also wanted Japanese subsidies given to aircraft production to be part of the negotiations. The United States wants European countries to end direct loans to Airbus, which it says has been the beneficiary of as much as $40 billion in government aid through low-interest loans used to help finance the development of new commercial aircraft. 
 The Europeans said that they were pursuing ways of reducing what they see as subsidies for Boeing but refused to go into details.
 Boeing officials were caught by surprise at the announcement but said that they had full confidence in Mr. Zoellick. 
 ''Boeing remains hopeful that an equitable agreement can be reached,'' Amanda Landers, a spokeswoman for Boeing, said, ''but the company continues to support the U.S. government's resolve to take any necessary steps to bring an end to subsidies.''
 Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, where Boeing employs thousands of people at its aircraft assembly plants, issued a statement Friday night applauding Mr. Zoellick.
 ''Today's move by the U.S. is the bold action we need to protect our workers and send a strong message to Europe that enough is enough,'' she said.
 The dispute stems from a 1992 agreement that outlined how governments could support their airline industries. Talks to review that agreement broke down last year over how to define government subsidies and whether the goal was complete elimination of those subsidies or simply restraint of them. 
 In their counterclaim to the United States' original filing at the W.T.O., European trade officials said the United States paid Boeing ''massive illegal subsidies that damage Airbus.''
 Since the original agreement, Airbus has surpassed Boeing as the world's leading supplier of commercial aircraft and the two companies are now poised to compete over a new generation of aircraft.

 at bottom, Airbus/Reuters)(pg. C2)

HEADLINE: President Bush's Debt

 BODY:
Last week, as Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain unveiled the commission on Africa's report to tackle poverty, Bob Geldof, the Band Aid star-turned-humanitarian, walked to the microphone with expletive-filled advice for how Mr. Blair and the British chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, should get the American president, George Bush, to step up to the plate on aid to Africa. Saving Africa, Mr. Geldof said, would cost ''half a stick of chewing gum a day'' for each citizen of the Group of 8 industrialized nations. 
 ''Tony and Gordon have to prepare to ring up George and say, 'Do this, George, do this one thing for me, it's going to cost you [nothing], do it for me,'' Mr. Geldof said. Any thoughts that Mr. Blair would disapprove of Mr. Geldof's rant were dispelled when the prime minister walked on stage and backed the aging rocker. ''Because I'm a politician in a suit, I wince at the occasional word, but, actually, what he said is really what I think.'' 
 As everyone knows, Mr. Blair has made Britain an unwavering member of President Bush's coalition of the willing in Iraq, at his own political peril. The favor he asked in return was a noble one -- for America to join other wealthy countries in substantially raising aid to Africa to cut poverty there. He and the architects of the United Nations' Millennium Development Project, to which America has signed on, say the number of people living in poverty around the world -- 1.1 billion -- can be cut in half by 2015 if rich countries donate 0.7 percent of their gross domestic product to development.
 Mr. Blair's report calls for African leaders to take responsibility for the part they have played in grinding the continent into the dust. It demands that they move faster toward democracy and stamp out corruption. But it also points out that wretched dictators and autocrats have been propped up by bribes, paid willingly by international corporations. 
 The aid and attention that have gone to Africa from Europe, Japan and America pale in comparison with what rich countries have been willing to squander on far less noble causes than providing drinking water for a 3-year-old in Chad. The report asks for an additional $25 billion a year in aid by 2010. With the right tools, Mr. Blair says, Africa has the same economic potential as Asia. 
 Mr. Blair will most likely be able to get most of his European colleagues on board this year. Less certain are Japan and -- most iffy of all -- America. So what will Mr. Bush do? Well, he will certainly point to his Millennium Challenge Account, which ties development aid to good governance. Indeed, the Millennium Challenge Account on Monday approved its first project -- $110 million to help finance, among other things, microcredit agencies, agricultural building centers and land title programs in Madagascar. 
 The Madagascar project and, indeed, the Millennium Challenge Account are both very worthy projects, and we applaud the Bush administration for the initiative. But they are not enough. They are not even close to what America can afford. It is long past time for Mr. Bush to stand shoulder to shoulder with Mr. Blair on Africa, just as Mr. Blair stood with Mr. Bush on Iraq. 
 Bob Geldof's language was over the top, but his point was right.

Editors' Choice
Other recent books of particular interest

POL POT: Anatomy of a Nightmare, by Philip Short. (John Macrae/Holt, $30.) A journalist's searching biography of the commander of the Cambodian killing fields in the late 1970's.

WHERE SHALL I WANDER, by John Ashbery. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $22.95.) New work from our great living poet of the interior landscape.

DR. KING'S REFRIGERATOR: And Other Bedtime Stories, by Charles Johnson. (Scribner, $20.) Religion, philosophy and African magic realism enhance these short fiction performances.

THE ORIENTALIST: Solving the Mystery of a Strange and Dangerous Life, by Tom Reiss. (Random House, $25.95.) The writer and impostor Lev Nussimbaum and his lives, 1905-42.

ESTER AND RUZYA: How My Grandmothers Survived Hitler's War and Stalin's Peace, by Masha Gessen. (Dial, $24.) A fine journalist's account of two indomitable ancestors.

SNOBS, by Julian Fellowes. (St. Martin's, $23.95.) A novel (his first) by the screenwriter of ''Gosford Park.'' Like the movie, it concerns the struggles of the upper class to stay upper.

THE CHRYSANTHEMUM PALACE, by Bruce Wagner. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A Hollywood novel by an insider who stirs up a great vat of steaming narcissism and status anxiety.

THE ROAD TO REALITY: A Complete Guide to the Laws of the Universe, by Roger Penrose. (Knopf, $40.) A big thinker on the big picture.

HEDWIG AND BERTI, by Frieda Arkin. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $23.95.) Arkin's second novel (she's 87) projects the inequities of fate on a German Jewish family from 1939 on.

THE GLASS CASTLE: A Memoir, by Jeannette Walls. (Scribner, $25.) Walls and her three sibs, dragged all over the country by damaged parents, thought it a glorious adventure. Tough kids.

EVERY MAN A SPECULATOR: A History of Wall Street in American Life, by Steve Fraser. (HarperCollins, $29.95.) A tale more cultural than financial, exploiting the street as an enduring symbol in American life.

HEADLINE: A Republican Stalwart Takes It on the Chin

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
JAMES A. GARNER, the mayor of the Village of Hempstead and one of the highest-profile black Republican mayors in the nation, lost his re-election bid last week, giving the Democratic and Working Families Parties a major victory in Nassau County.
 Wayne Hall, a Democratic village trustee who ran on the Working Families line, will become the first Democrat in decades to run the village when he takes office next month. He will also preside over a Village Board that for the first time in history will be made up entirely of Democrats. Mr. Hall's running mates, Lenora Long and Henry Conyers, won the two vacant board seats. 
 Mr. Garner was a four-term incumbent and had become prominent on the national and Republican stages in recent years. He is the immediate past president of the United States Conference of Mayors and was the Republican candidate for Congress last year in an unsuccessful race against the Democratic incumbent, Carolyn McCarthy.
 Desmond Ryan, a Republican lobbyist, said that while the village election was a relatively small race that drew just over 5,000 voters, it was a big blow to the Nassau Republicans. ''James Garner was the official that Republicans utilized to show that they were inclusive, that they could attract an African-American into their political tent,'' Mr. Ryan said. ''But it looks like they got him into the tent and then forgot about him.''
 Even Democrats thought that Mr. Garner might easily win re-election because the Democratic vote was likely to be split three ways since he was being challenged by Mr. Hall and two other Democratic trustees. But with an alliance forged between the Democratic and Working Families Parties, Mr. Hall rode to an overwhelming victory, with 2,334 votes to Mr. Garner's 1,546. Mr. Hall was listed only on the Working Families line, and its victory was its first in Nassau County.
 Mr. Hall railed against the village's high property taxes and its uncertain finances, with a credit rating that hovers near junk-bond status. Everywhere he went and in his campaign literature, Mr. Hall blamed Mr. Garner for taxes that have increased by 239 percent in his 16-year tenure and criticized him for doubling his salary to $118,000 while more and more streets fell into disrepair.
 ''These are the things that residents were talking about on the street,'' Mr. Hall said. ''And a lot of people just believe that it is time for a change.''
 Mr. Garner stood by his record. ''I have no remorse,'' he said on Wednesday. ''I've taken a suburban village and made it a thriving business center. I've put a brand new face on the village.'' He pointed to $400 million in economic development that he brought to the village and the building of new train and bus stations.
 Just days before the election, Mr. Garner announced plans to open a Costco Wholesale store on Main Street as part of his continuing urban renewal efforts. But Mr. Hall has consistently opposed urban renewal plans because they involve condemning and relocating homes and existing businesses. He said last week that he would re-evaluate the Costco plan, adding, ''That's a big question mark now.''
 Joseph N. Mondello, the chairman of the Nassau Republican Party, said Mr. Garner's defeat is the village's loss. ''He's done a great job over the time he's been in office,'' he said. Mr. Garner's failed run for Congress may have hurt him, Mr. Mondello said, with voters seeing it as a sign that he was ready to move on. 
 He said the Republican Party did not support Mr. Garner financially, but ''we supported him with people as best we could.'' But with Democrats outnumbering Republicans nearly 3 to 1 in the village, he said, ''it's been a growing difficult area for us.''
 Stanley Klein, a political science professor at the C.W. Post Campus of Long Island University, said that even if the Republican Party did not put any money into Mr. Garner's race, ''This is one that the Republican chairman of Nassau County can't duck.''
 The Town of Hempstead has always been the party's base, he said, and it has always won in the village despite high Democratic enrollment. ''This could presage impressive things for the Democrats countywide,'' he added.
 Jay Jacobs, the chairman of the Nassau Democrats, said Mr. Hall's victory ''demonstrated in a very difficult small race that the Democratic ascendancy in Nassau County is solid -- it's not fleeting.''
 Mr. Jacobs credited the partnership of Democrats, the Working Families Party and a community group, the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, known as Acorn, for the victory. He said the Democratic Party helped pay for campaign mailings while the Working Families Party and Acorn provided the ground troops that campaigned door-to-door and made sure voters made it to the polls on Election Day. The Democrats endorsed and supported Mr. Hall, but chose not to run him on the Democratic line to avoid a divisive primary.
 Dan Cantor, the executive director of the Working Families Party, said Mr. Hall's win is a big boost for his party, which has an enrollment of only about 250 voters in Nassau County. ''This may be the only time this has happened, but we were Row A on the ballot, and we beat a 16-year incumbent,'' he said. ''That's huge for us. It's our first high-profile race in Nassau County.''
 Mr. Cantor said his party decided to target Mr. Garner after he defeated a proposed ''living wage'' ordinance four years ago. ''This just shows that people are hungry for elections with content and that are driven by issues,'' he said.
 Mr. Ryan, the Republican lobbyist, said the election illustrated the growing influence of smaller political parties. ''This shows that these independent lines can't be taken for granted,'' he said. ''They have become an integral part of the process.''

HEADLINE: What Rising Young Designers Have Up Their Sleeves

BYLINE: By CHERYL JENSEN

 BODY:
WHILE it's not quite WrestleMania or ''The Iron Chef,'' a big auto show gives ambitious up-and-comers a chance to flaunt their skills and challenge the industry's established heavyweights.
 At the New York International Auto Show, on the level playing field of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, second-string automakers will flex their muscles against the giants on more or less equal footing. Here, a brilliant design study for a future model that fires the public's imagination can set the career of a young designer on an upward arc.
 The show, which opens to the public on Friday, affords trend watchers an opportunity to preview the work of the young designers who will be imagining the cars of tomorrow -- before they become the industry's stars of tomorrow.
 The designs that make it to auto shows are the best, said Geoff Wardle, associate chairman and director of advanced mobility research at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif. Getting a car onto the spinning turntables can supercharge a young designer's career. ''It's a very competitive business,'' he said. ''It's certainly a good start to have a show car or production vehicle attributed to your name.'' 
 Many of the industry's top design executives first won notice in their 20's and 30's with their visions of brash, innovative cars. 
 J Mays designed the Concept 1, which became the Volkswagen New Beetle, in his mid-30's; now, as vice president for design at the Ford Motor Company, he oversees the look of eight brands, from Aston Martin to Volvo. Bryan Nesbitt, General Motors' executive director for design in Europe, was 27 when he came up with the design for the Chrysler PT Cruiser. At 28, Anne Asensio found success at Renault in her native France with the concept for the Mgane Scnic minivan; she is now G.M.'s director for advanced design. More recently, the Chrysler 300's success made its 30-something designer, Ralph Gilles, a hometown hero in Detroit.
 In an effort to identify some promising but still unsung talents, The New York Times solicited names and examples from prominent designers and auto industry executives. Here are six -- others are profiled at nytimes.com/autos -- who were singled out, and the cars they will have at the New York show:

KENNETH LEE
NISSAN AZEAL
 When he was 5, Kenneth Lee was drawing cars on his Magna Doodle. In his fourth-grade journal, he wrote ''car designer'' in answer to the question, ''What do you want to be when you grow up?''
 His ambitions never changed. Now 27, he works at a sketch pad at Nissan Design America's new studio in Farmington Hills, Mich. He was there sketching when Shiro Nakamura, Nissan's senior vice president and design director, walked by, glanced at Mr. Lee's pad and sent the Azeal concept car on its way.
 Alfonso Albaisa, design director for Nissan Design America, said: ''To do a little coupe is not earth-shattering -- there's a million of them -- but every once in a while there's a design that just is so natural, and something that is all about what it is to be Nissan. We said, 'Let's go for it. Let's make a really beautiful coupe.'''
 Mr. Lee, who spent his childhood in Hong Kong before moving to California, graduated from the Art Center College of Design in 1999. He was at Ford's studio in Australia before joining Nissan less than two years ago. 
 The Azeal was designed to be a sporty entry-level coupe for someone who couldn't afford the Nissan 350Z or Infiniti G35 sports cars, Mr. Lee said. It hints at the design direction for a car smaller than the Sentra that Nissan has said it will produce in a couple of years.
 Mr. Lee noted that entry-level cars tend to have slab-sided bodies and tiny wheels tucked inboard of the fenders. ''We are doing the extreme opposite of that, pulling the wheels out to the corners,'' he said. ''The sloping roofline, the big fender flares, those are things you don't normally see on an economy car. I don't see why it can't be done in an entry-level car.''

AARON PIZZUTTI
JEEP HURRICANE
 Aaron Pizzutti's idea, which arrived rudely in the middle of the night, scared his wife half to death. But in the end his inspiration left Chrysler's chief executive, Dieter Zetsche, thrilled to death. 
 It all began in January 2004 when Mr. Zetsche issued this assignment: Come up with a vehicle that would be the ultimate expression of the Jeep brand. The ideas had to be ready by the end of the month.
 It was an important, daunting assignment for Mr. Pizzutti, 30, a Jeep enthusiast since high school and a designer at Chrysler for five years. ''You are pretty much thinking about it nonstop,'' he recalled. ''Day and night.'' The question was, What is the ultimate Jeep? The answer arrived one night around 1 a.m. 
 ''It honestly scared the death out my wife,'' he recalled. ''I sat up in bed and said, 'Oh my goodness, this is it! This is it! This is it!' I clicked on the lamp next to the bed, grabbed a piece of paper out of the nightstand and scribbled it down. My wife was like, 'That's fine. Now go back to sleep.'''
 So what was ''it''? A Jeep that could spin around on itself like a tank, with two big Hemi V-8 engines (one in front, one in the rear) and a body of exotic ultralight carbon fiber. In concept-car form, the Jeep Hurricane has a turning circle of absolute zero and a crab-steering mode that lets it move sideways without moving forward. Anyone who has done any off-roading, a passion of Mr. Pizzutti since his teens, knows those functions could come in handy. 
 ''These things don't happen all that often,'' said John Sgalia, Mr. Pizzutti's boss and director of the Interior-Exterior Jeep Studio. ''It was a wonderful creative moment that Aaron came up with it. Once we see that kind of gold, we've got to mine it.''
 Mr. Pizzutti, a Philadelphia native, has an engineering background and a design degree from the Cleveland Institute of Art. With that schooling, he understands the priority of function, Mr. Sgalia said, adding: ''At Jeep we are more function-driven. We design for a purpose as opposed to designing for pure emotion.''
 The Hurricane's abilities make it the most maneuverable, most capable and most powerful Jeep ever, and it met with the chief's approval.
 ''When Dieter saw that car for the first time, within five minutes -- in his three-piece suit -- he was lying on the ground underneath it,'' Mr. Pizzutti said.

VICKI VLACHAKIS
SATURN SKY
 The interior of the Sky roadster, which goes on sale early next year, posed some special challenges, but the interior designer, Vicki Vlachakis, had some special qualifications.
 By the time she joined G.M. in 2000 she had already worked for Mercedes-Benz in Stuttgart for four years. She also had an internship in Munich with Audi Design, renowned for the attention to detail in its interiors. ''She had perspective from a European company that is known for its design quality,'' said Clay Dean, G.M.'s design director for small and midsize cars. 
 It also made sense to have her as the interior designer on the Sky -- a crucial assignment, given G.M.'s hope that the two-seater will give Saturn some sex appeal -- because she had worked on the interior of its companion vehicle, the Pontiac Solstice.
 Differentiating the Sky's interior from the Solstice's was also a challenge, since the cars share some parts. But in another way it was easy, she said, because the Solstice uses classic feminine shapes while the Sky is more masculine.
 Ms. Vlachakis, 32, knew that designing the interior would be a challenge. ''A convertible is a special type of vehicle because you do see so much of the interior, so the form language had to meld together,'' said Ms. Vlachakis, who grew up in Pasadena.
 In design-speak, that means that the interior should reflect the themes of the exterior.
 ''On the exterior there are a lot of jewelrylike elements, with the chrome bar in the front and a lot of detail in the headlamps and taillamps,'' she said. ''We tried to bring the same sort of chrome, jewelrylike look to the interior.''
 Working from the design of an earlier European roadster concept, she fought to preserve that car's stylish interior trim, like the piano-black lacquer finish on the dashboard and console and the ''cobalt red'' accents on the leather seats, steering wheel and dashboard. The juxtaposition of the red against the glossy black lacquer and chrome ''is an impressive combination,'' she said. 
 Mr. Dean noted that Ms. Vlachakis struggled to get materials that would both provide the look she wanted and be suitable for mass production.
 ''You don't want to try to do something if you know you can't execute it correctly,'' he said. ''What it took was finding better finishes and better solutions so that it could be executed.''
 ''She really had to fight,'' he said. She did, and won.

GEORGE SARIDAKIS
FORD SHELBY GR-1
 Thanks to George Saridakis's passion for sleek design, the show-stopping Shelby GR-1 came to life in just three sketches over a weekend. Mr. Saridakis, 33, was born and reared in Crete -- his mother is Scottish and his father is Greek -- and he was just 8 or 9 when he saw a silver Citroen that made a big impression.
 ''It was a sleek-looking, bullet-looking thing,'' he recalled. ''It was like a spaceship at the time, very different from the cars I was familiar with. It really grabbed my imagination, and I just started drawing cars.''
 After earning a degree in aerospace engineering in Glasgow, he felt ''a wee bit cold, uninspired and somewhat unfulfilled.'' So he went on to design school and then spent three years at Toyota before joining Ford.
 The GR-1 is based on the Ford Shelby Cobra concept car from last year. ''We talked about doing something very sexy and very different from the roadster, said Mr. Saridakis, who speaks with a Scottish accent. ''I just started drawing these coupes.
 ''I ended up with three drawings very, very, very quickly. It was a joy, because the emotion was in my head: the feel of the car, the true nature of the car.''
 When it was finished, the look seemed familiar. ''I was drawing this car since I was 6 years old,'' he said. ''When I look at my schoolbooks back in Scotland or Greece, they are full of cars like this.''
 The front end resembles the Ford GT, but as a concept car -- a design study not necessarily destined for production -- ''it proposes a direction for Ford design,'' Mr. Saridakis said.
 Even now, with the gleaming GR-1 on display at auto shows -- it flaunts a shimmering skin of polished aluminum -- Mr. Saridakis is still surprised and perhaps bewildered by how quickly the design came to him.
 ''That's never happened before,'' he said. ''I just hope that happens again.''

JOSE PARIS
FORD SYNUS
 When Ford started looking for a design that would work on a car smaller than the Focus, it didn't want something that looked cheap or cute -- those approaches hadn't worked in the American market. Instead, designers wondered if the ''Built Ford Tough'' theme could work on a small automobile.
 Discussions led to the idea of an ''urban armadillo,'' a car with a tough-looking body but a warm interior. Jose Paris, 33, got the job of designing the exterior. 
 ''Jose did a very successful job of portraying toughness in a very small package,'' said Mr. Mays, Ford's vice president for design. ''In the sketch that I saw, the exterior looked almost like a Brink's truck. Then he took it to the next level by making it look modern.'' 
 The result was the SYNus, which stands for Synthesis-Urban Sanctuary. Synthesis refers to the combination of a tough exterior and an interior that is practically a cocoon.
 Although Mr. Paris has drawn cars since he was 3 or 4, his career began in architecture. But he kept drawing cars and eventually won a full scholarship to Art Center College. After graduating in 1998, he spent some time at Audi. He started with Ford in 2000.
 ''The best thing that I learned from architecture was to think,'' he said. ''They taught me, before you put your pen on the paper, you have to think about what you are doing and why you are doing it. Think about all the aspects of the project before you start.'' 
 Mr. Paris's background and life style gave him an advantage, Mr. Mays said, adding: ''He was born in Madrid and lives in what I can only describe as a very urban environment in the middle of L.A. So he understands urban environments probably as well as anyone in our design group, which was perfect for the SYNus.''
 The SYNus has been criticized for the image it conjures of American cities -- specifically, the perceived need to drive an aggressively styled armored vehicle as secure as a bank vault. But Mr. Paris disagrees. He describes it as having an attitude of ''don't bother me'' rather than ''get out of my way, little man.''

IAN CARTABIANO
TOYOTA FT-SX AND 2005 AVALON
 In 1994, when Toyota introduced the first-generation Avalon sedan, Ian Cartabiano was in his first year at the Art Center College of Design. As a 19-year-old he wasn't impressed. 
 ''I was more into sports cars, muscle cars,'' he said. ''I liked the Supra and Celica -- and the trucks.'' 
 Now 30, Mr. Cartabiano, who grew up in Torrance, Calif., practically in the backyard of Toyota's American headquarters, has designed the exteriors of both the new 2005 Toyota Avalon and the FT-SX crossover sport wagon concept. He was chosen to design the Avalon's exterior because ''his sketch really hit the mark,'' said Kevin Hunter, vice president for design at Calty Design Research, Toyota's California studio.
 ''It was an amazing, beautiful sketch,'' Mr. Hunter said. ''It was very elegant, very powerful, very sporty.''
 Without alienating the Avalon's core of older customers, Toyota wanted to give the car a more ''exuberant, expressive and sporty appearance'' to attract younger buyers. Mr. Cartabiano's creativity and enthusiasm ''helped us get to a new level,'' Mr. Hunter said.
 The challenge was to keep the familiar style of Toyota's flagship while making the Avalon look new.
 While his American bosses were enthusiastic, Mr. Cartabiano acknowledges that he was somewhat worried. He was competing within Toyota against designs from a Japanese studio.
 ''We had set out in the beginning with the key words 'American beauty,''' he said. ''We wanted to make an unabashedly American car, and we weren't afraid to say that. You're taking kind of a gamble. In a global company it's a risk to say, 'I'm going to make something that is American in almost everything.'''
 In the end, Mr. Cartabiano's American beauty won the pageant, and Toyota describes his Avalon as its ''most American'' vehicle: designed in California, engineered in Michigan and built in Kentucky.

HEADLINE: States and Communities Battling Another Round of Base Closings

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19 

 BODY:
For the first time in a decade, communities across the country are bracing for a major round of military base closings, and they are mounting aggressive lobbying campaigns to stave off cuts and other changes that some independent experts say could dwarf the previous four rounds combined. 
 Pentagon officials say all 425 domestic bases are under scrutiny, as the military looks to squeeze efficiencies and billions of dollars in savings from a cold-war network that has nearly 25 percent more capacity than what the armed services say they need. 
 After more than two years of exhaustive study, Pentagon analysts are putting the finishing touches on a list of recommendations that Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld will present to a nine-member independent commission for review. Scores of Pentagon analysts and auditors have been poring over data and dozens of options as part of an effort that is intended to mesh with Mr. Rumsfeld's broader goals to make the military more agile and responsive to security threats. 
 ''We know we have too much,'' Philip W. Grone, the deputy under secretary of defense for installations and environment, said in an interview. ''We know that we have capacity in the wrong place, either over or under. We're not well matched to the mission need.'' 
 State officials are rushing to preserve their installations, which provide thousands of jobs and billions of dollars to local and state economies. Florida, under Gov. Jeb Bush, has a $50,000-a-month contract with a consulting team that includes Dick Armey, the former House majority leader, and William S. Cohen, the former defense secretary. 
 Military officials assert that the Pentagon has no preconceived notions about which bases to close or consolidate, or the amount of annual savings. But senior military officials say the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines are likely to end up sharing more bases, laboratories, depots and training ranges in an approach consistent with Mr. Rumsfeld's philosophy that the armed services should fight and operate jointly. 
 One prominent military analyst, Loren Thompson of the Lexington Institute, said the military's excess industrial capacity made bases like the Army's Rock Island Arsenal in Illinois and the Watervliet Arsenal in New York, and the Marine Corps' logistics center in Albany, Ga., ripe for realignment. Such bases, while not widely known, employ large numbers of civilians.
 Mr. Rumsfeld will submit his list of recommended base closings, consolidations and realignments to the commission by May 16. A final roster of cuts and other changes, prepared by the commission, is due Sept. 8. Previous base-closing commissions have endorsed 85 percent of the Pentagon's recommendations. President Bush and Congress must then accept or reject the list by Nov. 7. 
 The Senate this week approved Anthony J. Principi, a former secretary of veterans affairs, as head of the Base Realignment and Closure Commission, widely known as the Brac. The White House also nominated the other eight members, which includes two retired four-star officers and two former congressmen.
 The four previous rounds of base closures, in 1988, 1991, 1993 and 1995, eliminated 97 bases and several hundred smaller facilities, and reduced overall capacity by 20 percent. These changes yielded savings of $28.9 billion through 2003, with recurring savings of $7 billion annually after that, according to the Government Accountability Office. This is the last scheduled round of closings, under the current model begun in the late 1980's, putting even more pressure on the decisions to come.
 Adding to the uncertainty of this year's round are the open-ended military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Pentagon's plans to bring 70,000 troops and 100,000 dependents in Europe back to bases in the United States, and a sweeping review of the military's strategy, forces and missions as required by Congress every four years.
 ''It's a new paradigm: we're at war and we're bringing people back,'' said Chris Kelley Cimko, a former Senate and base-closing commission official who is a member of a panel to save bases in Virginia. ''Have they been able to account for all of the thinking they're going to have to do to be effective in the future, and to have what might be the mother of all Brac rounds?'' 
 Mr. Rumsfeld last week offered comfort to some communities fearing closings, saying the large number of returning troops could soften the blow. Some bases may even expand with the troops' return. ''The number of bases that might be closed or adjusted downward in some way will be considerably fewer because we already have solved the problem of what we're going to bring back,'' Mr. Rumsfeld told the House Armed Services Committee. Legislators, lobbyists and consultants are ramping up campaigns, some of which have been two years in the works, to protect bases. 
 In Florida, Governor Bush and the state's Congressional delegation are waging a campaign to protect 21 installations that generate $44 billion a year for the economy, behind only tourism and agriculture in the state. 
 In California, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger appointed a California Council on Base Support and Retention, whose co-chairman is Leon Panetta, the former Democratic congressman and White House chief of staff. Mr. Schwarzenegger has also hired Clark & Weinstock, a Washington consulting firm headed by the former congressmen Vic Fazio and Vin Weber, to help protect California's military installations. Of California's 91 major bases in operation when the base closings began in 1988, 29 have been closed or realigned.
 During a recent conference of the National Governors Association in Washington, several governors, including George E. Pataki of New York, took part in a series of meetings with Pentagon officials to make pitches for their bases. 
 Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky has dedicated $660,000 from the 2004 to 2006 budgets to promote and preserve military installations in the state, including Fort Knox, which some state officials fear is vulnerable. In an effort to make her state's bases less vulnerable to closing, Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington plans to propose next week that the state set aside $10 million over two years to help repair or replace infrastructure around bases and to buy private property near bases to ensure an adequate buffer zone. 
 On Capitol Hill, lawmakers are lining up behind their installations. Last Wednesday, the Texas Congressional delegation summoned Mr. Grone and his top aides to voice support for the state's 17 bases and 150 smaller facilities, including Ingleside Naval Station, Goodfellow Air Force Base, and the Red River Army Depot, all of which survived previous closings but are considered vulnerable. 
 The process has generated anger among some lawmakers who say the Pentagon should not be considering closing bases when the nation is at war. Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, in an op-ed article in USA Today this month, called the base-closing commission ''a Congressional cop-out'' that depends on ''a paranoia-driven process that wastes time and money.'' 
 Proponents of the base-closing process say that since 1988, 107,000 jobs have been created in the communities where installations were closed or realigned. 
 Lawmakers and community leaders are searching for clues for what the Pentagon considers the most vulnerable bases, but any leaks of information have all but dried up because hundreds of military and Pentagon employees working on the process have been required to sign oaths of secrecy. 
 ''Far more than in the past, I think it is impossible to predict what will be on the list,'' said David Berteau, a consultant for Clark & Weinstock and a former Pentagon official whose responsibilities included overseeing base closings.
 The bulk of the analysis in the Pentagon is being carried out by seven groups of military and civilian officials who are organized to focus on these pivotal functions or organizations: industrial activities, supply and storage, headquarters and support, education, intelligence, medical and training. 
 The Pentagon teams are using several criteria to assess a base's value, including the base's mission, cost savings, availability of land and air space, and economic impact on local communities, aides said. 
 ''The outcome of Brac is going to be determined based upon a very extensive analytical effort that is examining capacity issues and military value issues and then the economics of the change,'' Adm. Vern Clark, the chief of naval operations, told reporters in January. ''In other words, I'm not remotely interested in changes that don't produce money.'' 
 In this round, Pentagon officials said, the Defense Department is looking at more shared or consolidated basing arrangements, either for cost savings or operational reasons. This could involve merging contiguous bases like Fort Bragg in North Carolina, headquarters of the 82nd Airborne Division, and Pope Air Force Base. Under some situations, Marine or Navy aircraft could fly from Air Force bases.
 It has been 10 years since the last batch of base closings, largely because Republicans accused President Bill Clinton of politicizing the 1995 round when he objected to the commission's decisions to close maintenance depots at McClellan Air Force Base in California and Kelly Air Force Base in Texas. Republicans said the administration was seeking to curry favor with voters in those big states by preserving those jobs. In the end, Mr. Clinton grudgingly approved the list. 
 In part because of that controversy, the rules were changed to require seven of the nine panel members to agree to any proposed additions to the defense secretary's list. A simple majority of its members may preserve a base that is a target of Mr. Rumsfeld.
 Congress created the base-closing process in the late 1980's as the military reduced in size in response to the collapse of the Soviet Union. With Congress unable to agree on which bases should be closed, a bipartisan Congressional group proposed turning the selections over to an independent commission.

Chart: ''The Road Ahead For Military Bases''
Pentagon officials say they are looking at all 425 military installations in the United States for the coming round of military base closings. The process will be handled by an independent commission, working from a preliminary list from Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld.

Main deadlines in the process

Secretary Rumsfeld
MAY 16 -- Rumsfeld must send his list of proposed closings to the commission and Congress.

Base-closing commission
JULY 1 -- G.A.O. must issue its analysis of the list to Congressional defense committees.

President Bush
SEPT. 8 -- Commission must send its list to President Bush.

SEPT. 23 -- Mr. Bush must either accept or reject the list in its entirety.

OCT. 20 -- Commission must issue revised list if Mr. Bush had objections.

NOV. 7 -- President must forward revised commission list to Congress.

Congress must disapprove of the list within 45 legislative days or before adjournment; otherwise it becomes binding.

HEADLINE: Playing Pin the Tail on the Donkey Just Won't Do

BYLINE: By JENNIFER ALSEVER

 BODY:
WHEN Chris Szarka threw a party for her daughter's first birthday at their home in Denver, the guest list included goats, ponies, chickens, rabbits and pigs.
 Ms. Szarka paid $275 for this personal petting zoo as part of an elaborate celebration for her daughter, Morgan, and about 60 human guests. Ms. Szarka handed out cowboy hats filled with barnyard toys and helped 20 children build their own stuffed horses.
 Years ago, birthdays were simple, with a handful of children playing in the backyard while mom lit the candles on the cake. Today, birthday parties are bigger and more elaborate than ever, with the guest list spanning entire preschool classes and price tags that can reach $1,000 or more. 
 And, as in so much of life, the pressure is on not to be outdone. Jennifer Neglia, a homemaker in the affluent community of Randolph, N.J., worries that her own children will think their parties are boring if she doesn't follow suit.
 ''It's almost competitive at this point,'' she said. ''I wouldn't expect to see favors at a party. But I feel like I have to have them at my party.''
 Ms. Neglia spent $350 on an elaborate tea party when her daughter turned 6. Her husband rented a tuxedo and served 18 girls who wore white gloves, ate finger foods, played whisper games, decorated straw hats, made pearl bracelets and had their photographs taken on a wing-backed chair. 
 ''It probably cost more than I wanted,'' she said. ''But we had a really good time.'' 
 It's tough to quantify how big the birthday business is for vendors, entertainment centers and suppliers, because no single organization tracks the children's birthday industry. But business appears to be booming. 
 The once-bankrupt Chuck E. Cheese leads the way, having opened about 30 restaurants a year for the last five years to reach 495 restaurants and sales of more than $654 million. The restaurants offer both walk-in dining for families and space for big parties. Rivals with names like Pump It Up and Monkey Bizness are opening in warehouses and strip malls, with amenities like 5,000-square-foot play areas and inflatable slides.
 But the definition of play area is expanding. Youngsters now celebrate with tea parties at bed and breakfast inns and visit nail salons for makeup and manicure parties.
 Hundreds of vendors rent inflatable castles with enclosed trampolines for backyard events, and parents can hire ice cream sundae caterers, storytellers, magicians, professional photographers, snake handlers and puppeteers. ''The market is exploding,'' said Frank Price, who owns Birthday University, a company in Raleigh, N.C. He gives business seminars to birthday service providers nationwide. 
 Working parents with two incomes but increasingly less time help fuel the trend. Parents have doubled their party budgets in the last three to four years, even as the economy has faltered, Mr. Price said. 
 ''Families and parents are looking for something unique and different that will give their child a lasting memory, and they're willing to spend almost anything to do it,'' he said.
 Perhaps most extravagant is the guest list. Today's parties can easily swell to 60 people, with children, siblings and parents. Some families invite the entire class so no child feels left out. 
 Susan Fagerstrom, a mother of two in Beaumont, Tex., said, ''You don't want 40 kids in your home.'' Many parents move the parties elsewhere so they can enjoy them, she said, and ''they don't think, 'I have to get the cake' or 'I need to clean this up.'''
 Ms. Fagerstrom said she and her two daughters, 5 and 7, attended 20 parties in the last seven months.
 ''I've been to parties at the movie theater, Chuck E. Cheese's, backyards with blowup slides, makeup and accessory parties, minigolf parties, puppet show parties, tea parties at home, roller skating and bowling parties,'' she said. 
 The multitude of invitations can also mean a multitude of gifts, and more pressure on parents. ''You want to give a nice gift,'' said Christine Driscoll, a mother in Ridgewood, N.J. ''You have 20 kids in a class. You get invited to 20 parties, and at $20 a pop, it just gets expensive.'' 
 Ms. Szarka, of Denver, admits that she has gone over the top on birthdays for her daughters, now 4 and 3.
 For her younger daughter's first birthday, she and her husband paid $50 to rent a clubhouse, $200 for machines to dispense cotton candy, hot dogs and popcorn, and $250 for a woman to give a Little Mermaid performance. 
 For another birthday, Ms. Szarka hired a $100 face painter for 20 guests, as well as a tea party organizer for $300, so the kids could don princess costumes and enjoy a tea party with miniature fine china.
 ''I like making my kids feel special,'' she said. ''It's the one day of the year where the focus is all on them. We spend a lot, but we don't buy them as many toys and we only do it once a year.'' 
 Parents like Ms. Szarka were clearly on Charlotte Cassese's mind when she opened a birthday party center called Glam Jam last spring in Randolph.
 For $300, parents can give a party for 10 girls at Glam Jam's warehouse operation, where guests create their own lotions, lip gloss and eye shadow. The girls, ages 6 and up, can then get their faces painted and dress up in boas and sunglasses for a red-carpet fashion show. A big-screen TV projects their images as they strut down the carpet. Parents can buy their own video of the show before they leave the event.
 ''YOU'D be amazed at what people will do for their birthday parties,'' Ms. Cassese said. One mother wanted a party for 40 children, but Glam Jam's limit is 20. So the woman held two parties -- one with 20 children on a Saturday and another the next day for 20 more. She spent a total of about $1,200.
 In the last two years, the warehouse area surrounding Glam Jam has seen the rise of a gymnastic center, rock climbing center, indoor soccer arena, ice-skating rink and two indoor play areas -- and all play host to frequent birthday parties. 
 ''This is the party place of Morris County,'' said Karl Lens, who runs Time In, a nearby 5,000-square-foot warehouse play area that has slides and equipment similar to those at a McDonald's. Mr. Lens, a father of three, started the business three years ago and is trying to open other locations through franchises. He said he runs about 600 parties a year, charging an average of $400 apiece. During the week, parents use the warehouse as a play space for smaller groups or individual children. But his expenses are substantial. Mr. Lens said he paid about $1,200 a month for insurance, while a single play system costs $50,000 to $100,000.
 Some families still prefer an old-fashioned approach. Christine Walker of Chicago, a mother of three, celebrated her son's fourth birthday last July at home. The children played in the backyard, with no organized games or entertainment. 
 ''We thought they'd have more fun playing with each other and in the yard, which they did,'' she said. ''I tell my kids what you have is really great -- not necessarily better, but certainly as good as other people's parties. I'd rather put $500 toward a 529 college savings plan.''

QUICK READ
Parents have a broad array of professional party planners to choose from. Here's a sample:

Dozens of home-based businesses offer to bring dress-up clothes and costumes to the house. Emily's Make Believe in Huntsville, Ala., will deliver up to five themes, including superhero garb and evening gowns, for $150. Noah's Ark Animal Workshop, in Crestwood, Ill., has sales representatives across the country who bring supplies to the home and help guests create their own stuffed animals. The price: $13 to $32 a person. AZ Little Chefs, in Phoenix, will send party hostesses to homes for $160 to help six guests decorate cookies or cakes or make meals like pizza and twice-baked potatoes.

A new generation of play centers offer inflatable or foam toys that children can bounce, jump and slide on. One nationwide business called Pump It Up has 65 franchised locations that play host to parties for about $250. American Girl offers parties at its New York and Chicago stores, with birthday packages for $32 a guest. Girls can enjoy three-course meals with their dolls in a private dining area.

Above, Kaitlin Schalago, 10, standing third from left, had friends help her put on a fashion show at her party at Glam Jam in Randolph. (Photographs by Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk; Ideas & Trends: Selling Social Security; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: How to Get Young People to Care About Old Age

BYLINE: By DAMIEN CAVE

 BODY:
TELL anyone under 30 how to save their money, and one of two responses is likely to surface: hot-blooded scorn or cold indifference. 
 Maybe that's why, despite his college tour, his bar graphs, statistics and stabs at humor, President Bush can't seem to persuade young voters to fight for his plan to partially privatize Social Security. 
 Recent polls show that the vast majority of 18- to 29-year-olds have only a hazy understanding of the White House's proposals, and more than 80 percent say they do not think the system is in crisis. Their response, at best, has been one big ''Whatever.'' 
 But according to marketing executives, economists and experts on youth culture, there are many ways to get young people to turn off their iPods and start paying attention. The key, they said, was understanding that young workers have a different psychological profile, one that embraces anger, celebrity and risk. 
 This generation has been shaped by turbulence. They soaked up the go-go, change-the-world Kool-Aid of the dot-com boom -- and watched it all go bust. They've seen superpowers self-destruct and witnessed the horror of Sept. 11. They've watched Fortune 500 companies implode, seemingly in days (Enron), and admired entrepreneurs who became billionaires in what seemed like nanoseconds (Google). Everywhere they look, individuals seem more empowered, while top-down institutions seem to be in decay and decline. 
 As a result, ''young people are as a whole more libertarian,'' said Bill Hillsman, chief creative officer of North Woods Advertising, which has created ads for Minnesota politicians like Jesse Ventura and Paul Wellstone. ''They love the notion of self-determinism.''
 Government, then, looks a bit boring and ineffective. And young workers, if they are planning for retirement at all, are surely not counting on Social Security. 
 ''This generation doesn't believe Social Security will be real for them,'' said Jack Schnirman, 27, the campaign director for United Leaders, a nonpartisan nonprofit group mobilizing voters 25 and under. 
 So the debate about ''saving Social Security'' seems irrelevant, he said, another example of an out-of-touch political culture, dominated by gray-haired stiffs who can't even set up their own e-mail accounts, let alone balance the budget. 
 ''It's not being fought about at our level,'' Mr. Schnirman said. ''It's at the grass tops, or Astroturf -- big phony 527's against other big phony 527's, like the AARP against USA Next,'' he said, referring to independent groups that run issue advertising. 
 Such cynicism, of course, is partly why politicians tend to ignore young people in the first place. But the president lacks that option, because he needs all the support he can muster. So, according to Mr. Schnirman and others, the first thing he needs to do is get out of the way. 
 Mr. Hillsman also placed emphasis on who delivers the message to young people. ''If you've got a demographic group that rejected or didn't embrace the chosen spokesperson for what you're trying to sell, you better find a better salesperson,'' he said.
 Some suggest replacing Mr. Bush with a star offering broader appeal -- like Donald Trump or Arnold Schwarzenegger. Or, the advice goes, the administration should focus on generational peers. ''Typically, young people themselves have more credibility, talking to each other,'' said William Galston, director of the Center for Information and Research on Civic Learning and Engagement, a youth-focused political research group. 
 But others argue that it's more important to change the message. Mr. Schnirman points out that the current White House sales pitch is dominated by stilted speeches and blobs of numbers about payouts, trust funds and dates like 2018 and 2042. ''You can't taste it or touch it,'' Mr. Schnirman said. ''It's very abstract.''
 A better approach, said Jennifer Colman, director of strategy for Wieden & Kennedy, the advertising agency for Nike, ESPN and Powerade, would be to hammer exclusively on the costs that are already being paid. Identify the Social Security deductions that shrink the salaries of every waitress, administrative assistant and entry-level analyst in the country, and make that money matter today, right now. 
 ''If the dialogue was about that line item,'' Ms. Colman said, ''that amount in your paycheck that you're not getting and may never get, that's the only sense of immediacy you can get with Social Security. That's probably the only hope, because it's an immediate concern.'' 
 Or why not try capitalizing on cynicism? Anti-smoking groups exploited that emotion effectively with their ''Truth'' advertisements, which highlighted the lies and dubious tactics used by the tobacco industry. A study found that those ads prevented about 300,000 youths from becoming smokers between 2000 and 2002.
 ''When you can point out to young people that someone is trying to pull the wool over their eyes, that works,'' Mr. Hillsman said. 
 Trent Duffy, a White House spokesman, said the administration is considering an array of options to reach young workers. ''We're very sensitive to it,'' he said. ''We will be doing lots of new and different messaging over the coming week, and talking to young people more directly.''
 And Republicans are aware that liberal advocacy groups will provide lots of competition. In a March 1 memo on Social Security, Rick Santorum, the No.3 Republican in the Senate leadership, wrote, ''We must be ready to defend against the MTV crowd and its partnerships with AARP, Moveon.org and the like.'' 
 Indeed, Rock the Vote, a liberal group that opposes the president's plan, will soon roll out an Internet and television ad campaign with the theme, ''Don't get ripped off.'' 
 To compete, the White House might want to up the ante. Robert J. Shiller, the Yale economist and author of ''Irrational Exuberance,'' an examination of the 1990's boom, said that for this generation, the investment options Mr. Bush's plan will probably offer -- low-risk bonds and stock-index funds -- are ''pretty dull,'' especially compared to the freedom people have when they invest online or with their 401(k) plans. 
 Young workers, he said, are likely to see the plans as paternalistic, designed by and for their parents. The White House, Mr. Shiller said, might consider offering economic transformation, in the form of more money to invest, or more options. 
 ''Young people today are captivated by poker,'' Mr. Shiller said. ''All this excitement that the president wants young people to feel can only happen when they are playing the game.''
