HEADLINE: Williamsburg Reinvented

BYLINE: By ANNA BAHNEY

 BODY:
IN the last decade, Williamsburg in Brooklyn has been a first stop for young people new to the city, just out of college. As they have grown up, the neighborhood has too, evolving from dive bars and movie rental joints to chic sushi restaurants and designer furniture emporiums. 
 Most of these Williamsburg devotees are now young professionals, often working in creative fields. They tend to be in their 20's and 30's and earning $60,000 to $150,000 a year, according to David Maundrell, president of Aptsandlofts.com, a real estate company in Williamsburg. 
 ''It is a small town of late 20- to 30-somethings,'' said Mr. Maundrell, who is 30 and grew up in East Williamsburg. ''They recognize people on the train going to work in the morning. Saturday mornings you go to walk your dog and get your coffee at 8 in the morning and someone else has the same routine.'' 
 In an area with little real estate to buy, these renters have been hungering for some equity of their own in a neighborhood that has become home, and not just a stopping-off point. 
 They are about to get their wish.
 This little hamlet is going to get bigger. Like a whole town bigger. Imagine all the owner-occupied housing stock of a town like Princeton, N.J., moved to this part of Brooklyn. Twice.
 More than 130 buildings are currently planned in Williamsburg and Greenpoint, the neighboring area to the north. They are but a curtain raiser for the large-scale waterfront developments that are anticipated with the proposed rezoning along the East River that will transform 75 blocks from industrial to residential use. Last Monday, the plan was approved by the New York City Planning Commission and now makes the next and last stop in the City Council before an expected approval in May. 
 The buildings under construction now -- some small, and tucked between low-slung neighbors, others rising above the rooftops with more than 200 apartments -- are just the beginning of a transformation that will some day make the neighborhood look very little like Brooklyn, and more like parts of the far West Village, with sleek glass high-rise buildings and waterfront residences. 
 Elan Padeh, the president and chief executive of the Developers Group, a consulting and marketing firm with 30 projects currently planned in this area, estimates that in the next two years there will be 3,000 to 4,000 new units in Williamsburg and Greenpoint. ''In the next four to five years,'' he said, ''10,000 to 12,000.''
 For people who are not only priced out of Manhattan, but shut out of the brownstone neighborhoods of Brooklyn like Park Slope or Brooklyn Heights because of price creep, the idea of a deluge of new construction is seductive: it will sell for $500 to $700 a square foot, half the price of Manhattan, and the tax abatements of 15 to 25 years will lower monthly costs. With a 30-year fixed mortgage on a $399,000 two-bedroom apartment with a tax abatement, buyers will spend about $2,500 a month, about the same as they would spend on rent in the neighborhood.
 But it isn't just economics. It is also aesthetics. 
 ''I like to design and build my space,'' said Jennifer Chan, 30, an architect who recently signed a contract on a one-bedroom apartment with high ceilings and a mezzanine in the Union Lofts building on South Second Street, around the corner from where she has lived for four years. ''It seemed like enough of a blank slate.''
 She said she had looked in Queens and other areas of Brooklyn for something that she could renovate, but after weighing the money and time decided that ''it seemed a lot more affordable to buy new construction.'' And she wanted to stay in Williamsburg. ''I'm very attached because my friends are there, the base of my social network,'' she said.
 Mr. Maundrell said he sees it all the time in his buyers. ''These people don't want to live in brownstone Brooklyn,'' he said. ''They are individuals or young couples. They aren't going to have much in common with the 50-year-old couple in Brooklyn Heights. Park Slope is another world. They look in Dumbo a little. But Dumbo doesn't have the sense of community.'' 
 Other brokers agree. ''Aesthetically, Park Slope is beautiful, but if you don't want to live in a house from 1860 and don't like gargoyles, it isn't for you,'' said Kara Kasper, an agent with the Corcoran Group who specializes in Williamsburg. ''To people coming from the East Village, Williamsburg feels like home and Park Slope feels like the suburbs.''
 But with so many developers breaking ground across the 11222 and 11211 ZIP codes and hiring architects with typically contemporary notions, will that community and cultural sensibility be maintained? Or will it run out in a wash of construction?
 They are building from Broadway in South Williamsburg, where the smoky aroma from the Peter Luger Steak House wafts, to the far northern reaches of Greenpoint and deep into East Williamsburg, where leafy streets like Ten Eyck and Scholes Streets recall ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn'' by Betty Smith. With most of the vacant lots already built on, three-story vinyl-clad houses and two-story garages are being replaced by glass towers that mimic those sprouting in Manhattan. 
 Many developers are rushing to get foundations laid to take advantage of existing zoning. New height limitations will go into effect when the new zoning plan is approved. Others are simply trying to capitalize on the interest in the market. 
 The neighborhood has come a long way in the past five years. Developers were long dubious that anyone would do anything but rent in Williamsburg. Originally, the conversion of the Smith Gray Building at 138 Broadway in 2001 was conceived as rentals. Mr. Padeh, who was with the Corcoran Group at the time and worked on the project, said that when the owner decided to sell the units, the expected price was $375 a square foot. The building sold for an average of $455 a square foot. (A 1,997-square-foot, three-bedroom penthouse is now available for $1.55 million, or $776 a square foot.)
 ''Based off of that success, the Gretsch Building was developed,'' Mr. Padeh said. ''No one would have taken a shot if 138 Broadway would have flopped.''
 The Gretsch Building, a 130-unit luxury building at 60 Broadway, was first offered for sale at the end of 2003 and sold for an average of $575 a square foot.
 Many of the largest developments in Williamsburg have not been done in the neighborhood's prime areas, which Mr. Padeh describes as the area immediately surrounding the L line subway station at North Seventh Street and Bedford Avenue, the streets on the perimeter of McCarren Park and, of course, the waterfront.
 Those who do sell apartments in the prime areas will get a premium. One building, an eight-unit building at 171 North Seventh Street, about 20 steps from the subway, recently sold for $735 a square foot. 
 Not long ago, North and South Williamsburg were areas where people could find deals. Now, they are just another option. The best bargains are in East Williamsburg, where buildings in territory better known as ''second stop'' and ''third stop'' on the L are selling out in a matter of days. 
 During an open house last week in East Williamsburg at a new condo building called the Nola, young buyers traipsed out into the cold and cooed at the view as the skyline of Manhattan turned pink on its jagged edges. 
 By the end of his first weekend of showings at the Nola, Mr. Maundrell, whose firm is selling the apartments, had accepted offers for seven of the eight units ranging from $399,000 to $650,000. Mr. Maundrell keeps a list of interested buyers and holds open houses for people to have an advance look at property coming to market. Next week he will have an open house for those on the reserve list for an 11-unit building on Ten Eyck Street with views of Manhattan called Tower 78. His list is already 200 people long.
 East Williamsburg became a viable place to sell, he said, when Manhattan went ''through the roof.'' And it helps, he said, that the new buildings have appealing design.
 Robert M. Scarano Jr., an architect based in Dumbo whose 60-person firm is leading the way, is working on 100 buildings in East Williamsburg alone. With a following mainly gained through word of mouth and support from developers who have seen the firm's work, Mr. Scarano does not have an exclusive broker for the properties but works with Corcoran, Prudential Douglas Elliman, the Developers Group and Aptsandlofts.com. ''We're like a Switzerland,'' he said.
 But the firm is really more like a young United Nations with architects, whose average age is 29, pulled from around the world. Thumbing through a two-inch-high pile of papers on a file shelf he said: ''This? This year's resumes.'' Moving to the shelf below it with a similarly intimidating pile, ''Last year's resumes.'' 
 It is no surprise. Mr. Scarano bestows an incredible amount of responsibility on his young staff, whom he wisely dispatches to design for people like themselves. 
 When Carmen Larach, a 25-year-old Honduras-born architect at the firm who lives in Greenpoint, finished designing 171 North Seventh Street with double heights and mezzanines, she knew exactly which unit she would love to live in. The top level, east side. ''The developers said, 'Let me make money on this one.' Maybe next time I can have one,'' she said. 
 In Mr. Scarano's office, one wall is all but covered with renderings. The mode for Scarano projects in Williamsburg and Greenpoint is a layered contemporary exterior with glass curtain walls. The quality of the finishes varies, based on the building, but stainless-steel appliances and granite countertops are practically standard issue. Buyers also want high ceilings, lots of light and outdoor space, he said. 
 Mr. Scarano is excited about the future of the waterfront and anticipates building in the rezoned area. He credits the likely changes to Amanda Burden, the chairwoman of the City Planning Commission. She ''is doing for Williamsburg what C. Virginia Fields did for Frederick Douglass Boulevard'' in Harlem, he said. 
 Of course, with so much building, everyone involved is wary of saturation. 
 Karl Fischer, the architect who designed the conversion of the Gretsch Building, has two of the most ambitious current projects: four buildings on Bayard Street, which runs along one side of McCarren Park, and a waterfront complex, Schaefer Landing, a joint venture with Gene Kaufman, an architect. He expects that the market will be flooded within a year or two after the rezoning takes effect. 
 ''It will actually be very good for the buyer,'' Mr. Fischer said. ''They will be able to shop around and have lots of product to choose from. Developers will have to try different things to compete.''
 For all its emulation of that island across the river, this northern knob of Brooklyn will remain the anti-Manhattan in at least one sense: it's a buyer's market.

What's Available in Williamsburg
 MOST of the condos now available in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, are selling for $500 to $700 a square foot. In the prime areas like the waterfront, parts of North Seventh Street and around McCarren Park, prices are $800 to $1,000. Here are properties currently available and a small sampling of things to come: 
 SCHAEFER LANDING, 446 Kent Avenue

Both sit behind a promenade along the river in South Williamsburg. The 14-story tower is 90 percent sold with two- and three-bedroom apartments with two baths available from $865,000 to $1.475 million; sales in the 24-story tower begin at the end of April. HEADLINE: All-Garden Alert! Aliens Have Landed!

BYLINE: By TOVAH MARTIN

 BODY:
MOST gardeners realize that when they plant a new patch of valerian, they risk offending some people's nostrils or they might disturb many of the neatniks in the neighborhood. But most residents of Connecticut aren't aware that if they purchase and transplant Valeriana officinalis (aka garden heliotrope), they are also in violation of Connecticut law.
 Valerian is one of the more commonly grown of the 61 non-native plants banned in Public Act No. 04-203 that came into effect in October 2004. Many of these plants with weedlike tendencies already have a longstanding reputation as thugs. 
 The law inflicts a $100 fine per plant for importing, moving, selling, buying, distributing and transplanting the banned plants. At present, thought, no person or agency enforces the law, and the fine is as contentious an issue as the ban. 
 Their crime? The banned plants are all non-natives (horrific though poison ivy might be, it is native and therefore is not on the banned list; ditto for the wild grape). All these aliens have become naturalized or occur without being planted. In other words, they've broken loose from gardens; they are wild. They spread rapidly by many reproductive methods under all sorts of growing conditions. And, here's the rub: they bully out natural plants. A full list is available on www.hort.uconn.edu/cipwg. 
 Oriental bittersweet (Celastrus orbiculatus), multiflora rose (Rosa multiflora), Japanese knotweed (Polygonum cuspidatum) and garlic mustard (Alliaria petiolata) commonly stage such reprehensible territorial takeovers that they've sullied their character with most people marginally aware of plant identification. Such ne'er-do-wells are not commonly on the market and no one in their right mind plants them on purpose. However, some of the flowering plants, vines, shrubs and trees on the list of offenders will come as a surprise perhaps even a shock to many state residents.
 Even the most astute gardeners might not realize that their Russian olive (Elaeagnus angustifolia), coltsfoot (Tussilago farfara), Scotch thistle (Onopordum acanthium), ground ivy (Glechoma hederacea), dame's rocket (Hesperis matronalis), cypress spurge (Euphorbia cyparissias) and ragged robin (Lychnis flos-cuculi) are botanical bandits. These and many other plants occasionally found in gardens are on the banned list. 
 Those gardeners who innocently add these botanical disciplinary problems to their yards not only court disaster on their own plot of land, but they can also wreak havoc elsewhere if seed is dispersed by wind, birds or other methods. As a result, invasive plants are deemed the second greatest environmental problem in the state, right behind the decline of open spaces.
 To tackle the issue, the Connecticut Invasive Plants Council was established in 2003, a committee of nine members representing diverse constituencies. The council studies and makes recommendations on which plants are invasive. 
 After much research ''the homework has definitely been done,'' according to Les Mehrhoff, of Willington and one of the council members, about the 61 plants shown to be such nuisances or potential nuisances to the environment that legislation was warranted.
 Although the banned plants are not economically important crops in this state, the 20 to be added in October of this year concern the nursery industry. Purple loosestrife (Lythrum salicaria), border privet (Ligustrum obtusifolium), yellow iris (Iris pseudacorus) and Japanese honeysuckle (Lonicera japonica) are among those commonly sold by nurseries but soon to be banned . The council is expected to recommend banning 15 additional plants, which will likely be a more volatile issue for nurseries. ''Some of these are big sellers,'' said Dr. Mehrhoff. ''But there has been a lot of work done documenting the invasiveness of these species. I don't understand how people can still say that these plants are not causing an environmental problem.''
 In the near future, there will be discussion concerning the banning of Japanese barberry (Berberis thunbergii) and its cultivars, which account for estimated annual retail sales amounting to nearly $5 million in Connecticut alone. The industry chalks up $4,490,000 in annual retail sales of burning bush (Euonymus alatus), also on the verge of being banned. 
 Many nurseries and merchants feel that they have been unduly targeted. 
 Bob Heffernan, executive director of Connecticut Green Industries, said, ''For the past three years, the state's response to the invasive plants problem has drifted off in a counterproductive direction, sadly preoccupied with penalizing and targeting flower shops, greenhouses, garden centers, nurseries and landscapers, instead of investing its energies and resources in solutions that really work.
 ''Management, eradication and public education -- those would be methods that work,'' he added. 
 Mr. Heffernan is strongly opposed to the ban approach, arguing that ''over 95 percent of the spread of invasive plants occurs naturally and innocently by wind, birds and uninformed people. No law can regulate a natural force.'' 
 Before the ban, Oliver Nurseries of Fairfield enacted their own voluntary moratorium of trees, shrubs and plants on the state's list of invaders. 
 ''We haven't experienced any loss of sales,'' said Jed Duguid, nursery manager at Oliver Nurseries. 
 Instead of such problematic plants as barberry and burning bush, Mr. Duguid steered his customers toward aronia, itea and spiraea. 
 In the case of barberry and burning bush, there are many varieties of the two plants sold at nurseries. Many in the nursery industry believe that the varieties, or cultivars, aren't as invasive as the parent species of the plant and they should be allowed to sell them without penalty. 
 Dr. Mehrhoff strongly disagrees. ''You can't separate the invasive tendencies of cultivars from species until scientific evidence proves otherwise,'' he said. In other words, he feels that cultivars are guilty until proven innocent.
 All agree on the necessity of public awareness and education about the problem. No money has been appropriated by the state toward that goal, but several Web sites are dedicated to informing about invasives. In addition to the Web site of the Invasive Plant Working Group, there is also the Invasive Plant Atlas of New England site at www.ipane.org. 
 In December, the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History opened an exhibition on Connecticut invasives. Titled ''Landscape Under Siege: Invasive Plants of Connecticut,'' which will be at the museum for a year. It features botanical paintings by members of the Greater New York Chapter of the Guild of Natural Science Illustrators coupled with commentary on the problem . Posters and flyers will also soon be distributed to increase public awareness and aid with identification.
 No one expects homeowners to eradicate all the Japanese knotweed or other banned plants from their property overnight and homeowners would not be fined if the plants were found to already be on their property. 
 ''Nobody's out to make it difficult for land owners on any level,'' Dr. Mehrhoff said. ''But, from this point on, we're going to be more logical about what we're putting on our landscape.''

HEADLINE: Walls That Speak of Status

BYLINE: By GARY SANTANIELLO

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S earliest stone walls were, in essence, linear landfills -- haphazardly stacked, post-Colonial piles of stone laboriously cleared from rocky fields by upland farmers. 
 The newest stone walls are a different story. The majority are beautifully designed, carefully crafted complements to residences ranging from million-dollar mansions to modest Capes. And they are ubiquitous. 
 ''Every time you turn around, you see a new one going up,'' said John Giunta, a contractor in Westport who has been building walls for 43 years. 
 Keith Manca, a Danbury home builder who does most of his work in Fairfield, said that in lower Fairfield County stone walls had become a status symbol, like driving a Mercedes-Benz. ''The last couple of years it's been out of control, the amount of stonework going on,'' he said. 
 Many factors are driving this trend. A superheated real estate market is forcing builders to provide additional amenities while motivating homeowners to improve their property. There is a much greater availability and variety of stone, as well as more tradesmen doing the work. There is a renewed appreciation for the iconic ''farmer's walls'' that still cover the state, reminders of its agricultural past. And there is a familiar suburban motivator: envy.
 ''It's almost like trying to keep up with the Joneses,'' said Bill Osborn of Easton, a landscaper who built his own 200-foot wall from stone on his property. 
 Edgar Avila, who learned masonry from his father in his native Ecuador and has owned a masonry and landscaping business in Danbury for six years, said that clients were asking for more than just walls.
 ''People are asking for patios, steps and pillars in the driveway with the stone they see in old-fashioned New England-style walls,'' he said.'' They want them to look like they've been up a long time. Some of my customers are asking for the new kinds, but they don't like it if it looks too perfect.'' 
 Real estate agents explain the phenomenon in terms of curb appeal. 
 ''If you look at how property values have escalated, curb appeal has a lot to do with the value of a property,'' said Joyce Robinson, an agent with William Raveis Real Estate in Westport, ''and stone walls in general are a very appealing part of Connecticut.''
 What is remarkable, real estate agents and builders said, is the extent of stonework being done, particularly in new construction. 
 ''A good portion of the total project now is being spent on stonework,'' said Janet Perreca, an agent with Coldwell Banker Mabel Lamb in New Canaan. ''Buyers are expecting more than a few little bushes when it comes to extras. They want stone walls and pillars.'' 
 Louie Ten, a landscaper based in Westport for 17 years, said, ''Go to any new development, you'll see they're trying to incorporate some stonework into it.''
 Depending on the quality of the home, such masonry can constitute 1 percent to 10 percent of a home's value. ''On a $2 million home, if you spend money on stonework, you'll get a quicker sale and a happier customer,'' Mr. Ten said. 
 Although opinions vary on whether the higher-end demand is builder- or buyer-driven, there is agreement that customers are increasingly demanding and savvy.
 ''In this town especially, people want a certain thing,'' Ms. Perreca said of New Canaan. ''They expect certain things, like stone fronting and expensive detail when they purchase a $2 million starter home.'' 
 Before Lance and Pamela Graber built their house in Westport in 2001, ''We knew we wanted a fair amount of stonework,'' Mr. Graber said. ''We wanted to do something different from what, at the time, was being built around town, which were center-hall Colonials.'' 
 The Grabers also wanted a formal wall in front that reflected the look of the house and blocked noise from the street. 
 ''It's funny, but when we built it we thought it was a little unique,'' Mr. Graber said. ''People always are looking to do something different from what other people are doing, but as more and more do it, there will come a point when everybody's doing it.'' 
 Alyssa and Raymond Mocco had lived in a house on Morehouse Road in Fairfield for four years before having a wall built in front two years ago. Part of the reason was to prevent their young son from wandering into the busy street, but not all of their motivation was practical. 
 ''I grew up with stone walls,'' Mrs. Mocco said. ''My dad, an electrical engineer, built them all over our property in Trumbull. My husband's from New Jersey, and he loves seeing them in the woods all around here.'' 
 ''I just love the way they look,'' she added. ''I love being outside, and unlike a fence, which is man-made, a stone wall makes us feel like we're a part of nature.''
 When Bill Shaffer, an architect in Westport, renovated his house to incorporate an office, he also added a gently sweeping, flat-arch wall made from three kinds of granite fieldstone to the new front of his house. 
 ''As an architect, stonework has always been a big part of my thinking,'' he said. ''There's a timeless quality to it. It gives a home character and permanence that today's materials don't. I think professionals are pushing stone because it's a beautiful material. It's natural, and you don't have to worry about maintenance.'' 
 It is also one of the few building materials that look better over time. ''The older it gets, the better it looks,'' Mr. Manca said. ''It disappears into the landscape.'' 
 Mr. Ten characterized the interest in stonework as a ''follow the leader type of thing.'' After he built a stone wall along the sides of his 300-foot driveway, he said: ''Every single neighbor came up to me and said, 'Can you do something like that for me?' They can see it's a dramatic change.'' 
 The cost varies widely. For her 150-foot-long, 3-foot-tall wall, Mrs. Mocco received estimates from $9,000 (labor only) to $25,000 (labor and materials).
 Depending on the stone, the terrain, the experience of the mason and the complexity of the wall, the overall construction can cost from less than $10 per square foot to more than $100, and Mr. Giunta said his rates had run as high as $150 per square foot because of the stone involved. 
 Mr. Giunta said that although it seemed as if every landscaper were doing stone walls, ''there are a lot of skilled people out there doing it now.''
 ''Some of the people from Brazil and Mexico are craftsmen,'' he added. ''They're good.'' 
 Mr. Ten said there was much ''phenomenal work being done; a lot of techniques, a lot of styles.'' 
 ''But,'' he added, ''there are some walls, a deer clips its hoof on the wall and part of it falls down.'' 
 The stone, including used or reclaimed stone, is readily available from suppliers throughout the state. Because of the popularity of old stones, though, some have been stolen from existing walls. Robert Thorson, a geology professor at the University of Connecticut and author of three books on stone walls, said he had heard many accounts of such pilfery, including one in which a woman noticed a commuter stopping at her wall and taking one old stone each day.
 Although the majority of the newest walls are built with aesthetics or economics in mind, some arise from more prosaic reasons. When Mr. Osborn found himself with surplus stone, he started rebuilding a wall on the edge of his property that had fallen into disrepair. ''It's almost up to my chin in some places, and the base is five feet wide,'' he said. ''I call in the Great Wall of China -- you can walk on it.'' 
 From an 800-foot wall on Beachfront Avenue in Westport to a job in Redding that took more than two years to complete (''Fireplaces, terraces, the whole package''), Mr. Giunta has done all kinds of high-end masonry, indoors and out. ''I've even done waterfalls inside people's houses,'' he said. 
 Still, the quality and the distinctiveness of the walls today amaze him. ''It's incredible,'' he said, ''how stone is being used now.''

HEADLINE: Markets Take a One-Two Punch and Stocks Fall

BYLINE: By JEFF SOMMER

 BODY:
Beset by rising oil prices and a report that consumer confidence has been declining, the three major stock market indexes dropped again last week.
 Crude oil and retail gasoline prices both climbed during the week, while the University of Michigan's preliminary confidence index fell in March, the third consecutive monthly decline. 
Federal Reserve policy makers are expected this week to raise interest rates by another quarter of a percent. 
 Trading volumes were high on Friday because of the expiration of futures and options contracts and a shift in Standard & Poor's method of calculating indexes. 
 Exxon Mobil gained 2.6 percent for the week, the biggest advance in the Dow Jones industrial average. General Motors, which forecast a big quarterly loss, fell 16.7 percent. 
 For the week, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 10.43 points, or 0.9 percent, to close at 1,189.65. The Dow fell 144.69 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 10,629.67. The Nasdaq composite index shed 33.81 points, or 1.7 percent, to close at 2,007.79. 
 The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell to 4.51 percent from 4.54 percent the previous week. JEFF SOMMER

HEADLINE: Crowds? No, Thanks. Same for Grants.

BYLINE: By HUGH EAKIN

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS 

 BODY:
IT sounds like a familiar story. On April 17 the Walker Art Center here will unveil a head-turning $92 million expansion designed by the hot Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron. Along with spectacular galleries, it will offer a Wolfgang Puck restaurant, a Wi-Fi-networked lounge and enough sex appeal to turn the place into the most talked-about new building between the coasts.
 In other words, just another museum banking on some iconic real estate to enhance its brand and ramp up its gate revenues. Or is it? 
 Actually, the point was never to draw huge crowds. The celebrity of the chosen architects was accidental, even a matter of concern. And while one of the most distinctive features of the new building is a technologically sophisticated performance space, it can't hold even 400 people. 
 Welcome to the contrarian world of the Walker, a place that prefers artful provocation to blockbuster entertainment, privileges the obscure and experimental over the tried-and-true, and cultivates a willful insouciance about the forces that govern most big museum establishment. 
 ''We did wonder at times about our sanity,'' said the Walker's director, Kathy Halbreich, as she showed a visitor a new $25 million underground parking garage, punctuated from above by the boxlike housing of a new James Turrell installation. ''But once that retaining wall went in, it was very hard to turn back.'' 
 Like so many other institutions, the Walker has decided to grow a size or two, with all the usual trimmings. But Ms. Halbreich, whose colorfully nonconformist views about contemporary art and its audience have shaped the project from the beginning, has made sure that is where the similarities end. 
 ''Of course it's risky,'' she reflected. Plain-spoken and down-to-earth, Ms. Halbreich, 55, wears her elite-museum-director status lightly. On a recent late-winter morning she was dressed in a beige sweatshirt over jeans. She might easily have passed for one of the workers still hammering away at the building were it not for a pair of chandelier earrings and a large bracelet.
 But she doesn't hide an uncompromising vision and a firm conviction that a free-spirited institution in the Upper Midwest, well away from the East and West Coast bastions of the art world, is best equipped to carry it out. Among other things, her insistence on creative independence has meant turning down a chance at tens of millions of dollars in state support, despite a financial crisis that has crippled the Walker's endowment and led to painful staff cuts. 
 ''There are very few places that would be as idealistic as we are in building this,'' said Ms. Halbreich, who was raised in New York City and was the first curator of contemporary art at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston before taking over the Walker in 1991. Although she has been a curator of acclaimed shows of marquee artists like Bruce Nauman and Chantal Ackerman, she is fond of ripping into hierarchies of taste, prestige and genres that often prevail elsewhere. (At a recent panel discussion she playfully contradicted two fellow museum directors, Glenn D. Lowry of the Museum of Modern Art and Philippe de Montebello of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, commenting that ''part of the alienation people feel'' from the art world is the ''authority that our institutions bear almost to a fault.'')
 But idealism has a long pedigree at the Walker, which has evolved in a city known for its outsize arts patronage. For decades the center has flourished as an alternative to conventional art museums and rarely witnessed excessive lines at the ticket counter. (It attracts more than 400,000 people a year, healthy by contemporary art standards.) 
 Under Martin Friedman, the former director, the center became one of the most exciting places to see emerging talent. Merce Cunningham and John Cage performed here in the mid-1960's , when they were not much more than a wandering bus caravan. In 1986 the Walker presented the first museum show devoted to the designs of a still widely unknown Frank Gehry. More recently Ms. Halbreich -- with an ambitious new team of curators -- has embraced non-Western art, introducing visitors to such world talent as the Ethiopian artist Julie Mehretu and (later this year) the Chinese painter Huang Yong Ping, while encouraging established names like Dan Graham and Shirin Neshat to explore different genres.
 At the same time, she has introduced programs to draw teenagers, local artists and members of Minneapolis's booming immigrant population. 
 ''Kathy has created a completely utopian institution that also happens to be a large, well-functioning museum,'' said the New York art dealer Barbara Gladstone. 
 But by the late 1990's the Walker had long since outgrown its restrained modernist home, designed in 1971 by Edward Larrabee Barnes. The challenge of the expansion, Ms. Halbreich said, was to create a physical form for the Walker's open-ended programming -- and figure out how to pay for it. Museum officials quickly hit it off with Mr. Herzog and Mr. de Meuron, but they kept looking because, as the chief curator, Richard Flood, explained: ''It was too good. They seemed too gemutlich with us, too soon.'' 
 There was also the issue of the Swiss architects' reputation: having already designed the much-hyped Tate Modern in London, they hardly qualified as the emerging talent that the Walker prides itself on. ''They agonized about this,'' said Thomas Fisher, dean of the architecture college at the University of Minnesota. 
 There was some consolation in the fact that the Herzog and Meuron studio was not a household name -- this will be its first completed American museum. The new structure makes for an exuberant contrast to the building it adjoins. Sheathed in a facade of perforated metal panels interrupted by trapezoidal windows, it is angular but unpredictable; its primary element is a twisted, cantilevered cube that pokes fun at the traditional museum box. 
 Inside, the building is intended to raise similar challenges to museum orthodoxy, with a layout dictated by a system of interconnected moderately sized public passageways rather than by the galleries. Minneapolis suffers from a dearth of indoor public spaces; the Walker's design team set out to make a building that small groups would want to linger in, whether or not they were there for the art.
 ''I've been criticized for saying we looked at Mall of America, and we did,'' Ms. Halbreich said. ''It's not that we wanted to be that, but we wanted to understand it.'' (Mr. Herzog, the architect, prefers to compare the spaces to an Arab bazaar.)
 In the galleries, the Walker deploys its rich holdings in areas like Minimalism, Arte Povera, video and the Fluxus movement to challenge the dominant New York narrative of postwar art. For example, a group of Abstract Expressionist works in the new installation will segue into a series of Gutai action paintings that appear to draw on much the same language but were created by Japanese artists with no knowledge of what was happening in New York. 
 Perhaps the most striking feature of the addition, aside from a museum store that is smaller than before, is the sui-generis performance space. A hybrid of intimate black-box theater and massive high-end stage, it has all the flyspace and technical capabilities of a large contemporary auditorium or opera house, with perhaps a tenth of the seats. The idea is that artists can come to try out new works, which, if successful, can be sent on the road without retrofitting for bigger stages. But there will be no pressure to do crowdpleasing fare. ''If we get 50 people, it will seem like a good audience,'' said Philip Bither, the performing-arts curator. 
 Such artist-centric features are bound to help the Walker keep its creative edge, but who is going to pay for them? 
 Early on Ms. Halbreich decided that the capital campaign for the project should be privately financed, although the state of Minnesota has given sizable support to other arts institutions. With the state government's recent swing to the right, the move has been praised by leaders in traditionally liberal Minneapolis. ''The N.E.A. controversies of the 1990's'' -- fueled by a now-infamous performance piece at the Walker by Ron Athey, an H.I.V.-positive gay man -- ''demonstrated that government help can also mean government interference,'' said R.T. Rybak, the mayor of Minneapolis. (The Walker still receives a modest amount of operations funds from the state and the National Endowment for the Arts.)
 Still, the picture began to look a lot different after 9/11 and the stock market downturn. The Walker's endowment plummeted $62 million -- almost one-third --and attendance fell by a similar margin. The board considered canceling the expansion. In the end, Ms. Halbreich settled on a one-year salary freeze, and, in May 2003, eliminated the Walker's new-media art program and the job of its curator, Steve Dietz. 
 The decision led to an international outcry and called into question whether the Walker was staying true to its mission after all. Instead of spaces devoted to changing shows of new-media art as planned, the new building will offer only a few interactive work stations, designed primarily as learning tools. 
 While calling it ''the toughest personnel decision I have ever made,'' Ms. Halbreich said she did not regret it, and still hopes to revive the program. (Mr. Dietz, contacted by e-mail, declined to comment.)
 Since this setback, Ms. Halbreich has nonetheless been successful in selling her purist mandate to deep-pocketed patrons. The center has raised $87.5 million of its $92 million goal, a large part of it from trustees. And for all her stubborn resistance to market-driven concerns, she has managed to woo such Minneapolis-area corporations as Target, Medtronic, Best Buy and General Mills, several of which are represented on her board. ''It's somewhat counterintuitive,'' said Nazie Eftekhari, a Walker trustee and vice chairwoman of the capital campaign committee. ''Kathy has these conservative organizations acting in a very progressive manner.'' 
 By her own account, Ms. Halbreich has a good deal more business sense than she lets on. But it also doesn't hurt, she said, simply to be forthright. ''I'm honest. People know what my values are,'' she said. 
 She added, ''All we're trying to do is create this very sensuous wrapper for new ideas about the world.''


CORRECTION-DATE: April 3, 2005

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 20 about the expansion of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis under the leadership of its director, Kathy Halbreich, credited her incorrectly with a first. The first curator of contemporary art at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, was Kenworth Moffett, who held the title part time from 1971 to 1978.

HEADLINE: What? They Never Heard Of WorldCom?

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
WHAT a week. 
 Bernard J. Ebbers, founder of WorldCom, got to add felon to his already colorful curriculum vitae. Maurice R. Greenberg, dictator in chief at American International Group, the global insurance giant, was toppled after almost 40 years at his post. The Federal Reserve told Citigroup it could not make any major acquisitions until it cleaned up its compliance act. And General Motors laid a big, scary earnings egg. 
 Isn't it nice to know these incidents are anomalies and that most American companies are chugging along, reporting good solid earnings?
 Sure would be. But contrary to popular belief, the quality of corporate earnings is on the slide again and, as a result, Richard Bernstein, chief United States strategist at Merrill Lynch, is advising investors to tread carefully.
 ''There is an impression that the quality of earnings has improved dramatically,'' he said. ''That is true relative to the worst levels of post-bubble reporting, but relative to history, the absolute quality of earnings is quite poor.'' 
 And getting poorer.
 Mr. Bernstein reaches this depressing conclusion by analyzing the difference between the earnings that Standard & Poor's 500 companies have reported under generally accepted accounting principles and operating earnings, the figures companies typically trumpet because they do not include write-offs and other unusual items. 
 The difference between the two figures, Mr. Bernstein says, is the G.A.A.P. gap. 
 And it is widening. In the most recent period -- the fourth quarter of 2004 -- the gap was 13.7 percent. In other words, operating earnings were on average 13.7 percent higher than reported earnings. While that figure is well down from the 40 percent gap reached in 2002, it is much higher than the long-term, pre-bubble average of 6.7 percent. 
 The result: while stock valuations may not be so high as they were before the bubble burst, the quality of earnings appears to be worse. 
 Of course, none of this might matter if investors bought stocks based on G.A.A.P. earnings. But too many buy shares based on what companies report in their press releases and on their quarterly conference calls, which are often heavily skewed to earnings before the bad stuff. 
 ''The fact is, stocks trade on press releases, on what the headline number is,'' Mr. Bernstein said. ''And on the conference calls, companies talk about whatever numbers they want to talk about. Investors should still be very skeptical of the quality of earnings.''
 Mr. Bernstein said that he thought the recent downturn in earnings quality began, not surprisingly, a couple of quarters ago, when the profit surge started to subside. ''If times are good, companies are not under pressure to keep their growth profile up,'' he said. ''In tough times, when you get a cyclical company that has been coined by the Street as a growth company, it feels pressure to keep up that profile.'' That's when the earnings games usually begin.
 By focusing on operating earnings, rather than on more stringent reported figures, companies try to steer investors away from mistakes such as asset write-downs or restructuring charges. But these factors reflect bad choices by managers -- such as overpriced acquisitions -- and should definitely not be excluded from investors' analyses. 
 ''The difference between operating and reported earnings is an indication of how well executives are managing the balance sheet of their company,'' Mr. Bernstein said. This is often lost on investors who pay little heed to the balance sheet. 
 The five companies with the widest gap between reported earnings and operating income currently, according to the Merrill Lynch analysis, are: Eastman Kodak; Georgia Pacific, a paper products company; Rowan Companies, an oil drilling concern; Ford Motor; and Clorox. 
 Mr. Bernstein said the vast majority of companies with the biggest gaps between reported earnings and operating income are of lesser-quality, those whose common stocks are ranked B or below by S.&P.; among the five with the widest gap, all are rated B or below except Clorox, which is rated A. So investors can often limit their exposure to earnings shenanigans by sticking with high-quality issues. 
 But such a strategy won't offer full protection. As Mr. Bernstein noted, 22 percent of the companies with the largest gaps between reported and operating earnings were rated B+ or better by S.&P. 
 Mr. Bernstein said he thought the earnings games would be curtailed sharply if the Securities and Exchange Commission required that all company communications with investors reflected figures computed in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. 
 Then there would be no confusion among investors about what a particular company really earned in a quarter. 
 ''The reason you have G.A.A.P. is so investors have consistent clear information,'' Mr. Bernstein said. ''The U.S. has always prided itself on having the most transparent financial markets. 
 ''But over the past 5 to 10 years, the U.S. market has become more opaque, and foreign markets have become more transparent. That has huge implications for the economy as a whole and for the cost of capital.''

SUBJECT: STOCK INDEXES (91%); COMPANY EARNINGS (90%); FINANCIAL RESULTS (89%); ECONOMIC BUBBLE (88%); INSURANCE (77%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (77%); BANKING & FINANCE (77%); ACCOUNTING STANDARDS (76%); INVESTMENT ADVISERS (69%); SECURITIES TRADING (66%); CONFERENCE CALLS (60%); ACCOUNTING (51%) Terms not available from NYTimes

HEADLINE: Understudies Get to Play a Leading Role

BYLINE: By Tanya Mohn. 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
ON a brisk afternoon recently, six actors and a stage manager arrived promptly for auditions at Middle School 201/Star Academy in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx. The actors were not trying out for roles on Broadway or in a film; they were hoping to land jobs as substitute teachers.
 In an environment where finding qualified teachers is hard enough, and finding good substitutes even harder, a program based in the heart of the South Bronx has begun recruiting professional actors as substitute teachers to help children improve literacy and gain self-confidence. 
 ''They exchange hats, learning from each other,'' Howard Katzoff, a teacher and the coordinator for the program, Starrr Drama, an acronym for Substitute Teachers for the Arts and the three R's, said of the two seemingly disparate groups: trained actors in need of regular income and students in need of enrichment. 
 Instead of a nonproductive day, which is often the norm when teachers are absent and substitutes are brought in, students learn playwriting and storytelling and the actors gain valuable training and flexible work that pays $127 a day.
 John Herrera, who has been a substitute teacher for more than a year in the Starrr program, appeared last spring in the New York Philharmonic's production of ''Candide'' at Lincoln Center and was able to teach during the day and perform at night. He returned to the classroom after spending most of last fall performing out of town in ''Anna in the Tropics.''
 He recently taught a class of eighth graders at M.S. 201, one of several schools where he regularly substitutes, gearing his lesson around ''The Green Bean Patch,'' a short story that was set in East Africa during a famine and was excerpted from a play by Jonathan Kariara.
 In the morning, the class read the story aloud, then broke into groups to write scripts based on the story. After lunch, some students read the draft scripts aloud while others listened and critiqued.
 ''I never knew I could do it,'' said Ada Cuevas, 13, whose brief performance as a woman whose son dies brought a noticeable hush to the room. 
 Isaac Ofori, also 13, was the lead playwright for one script chosen to be performed. He said that when his class usually has substitute teachers, ''it's the same old thing, day in, day out.'' 
 But, he added, ''When we get a sub like this, we learn something new and even fun.'' 
 Mr. Herrera stayed after class to meet with the actors who had come to try out for jobs as substitutes, explaining that he chose an African folk tale because he felt that the students, who come from different backgrounds, could relate to it. He also told the actors how he used theater exercises -- including having the students clap and stamp their feet in patterns -- to help them develop their concentration and to relieve stress at the end of a long day. 
 ''Sometimes you feel like you're doing missionaries' work,'' Mr. Herrera said, explaining that few in the class had ever gone to a play. ''But by the afternoon, they were actable.''
 The seven substitute-teacher candidates who auditioned had selected a Langston Hughes poem to show how they would teach literacy skills.
 ''It's a workout for acting skills,'' Mr. Katzoff said, explaining that the challenge for the actors is in interpreting works imaginatively and holding the attention of their young audience.
 Mr. Katzoff said he first considered hiring retired teachers as substitutes, but a drama teacher suggested actors. New York had struggling actors on every corner with the confidence and the communication skills to work in a classroom, Mr. Katzoff thought, and hiring them would also allow him to bring some drama instruction to schools that did not have regular programs. 
 Mr. Katzoff ''showed up on my doorstep,'' recalled Kathy Schrier, managing director of the Actors' Work Program, which is run by the Actors' Fund of America. The program founded Starrr in partnership with Region 2 of the New York City Department of Education. 
 A pilot program that was started in February 2003 in two schools has grown to include 14 elementary and middle schools. Fifty actors have been trained and licensed as substitute teachers. Some have gone on to become full-time teachers.
 ''The bottom line is, it's a program that works,'' Ms. Schrier said. ''Everybody benefits.''

HEADLINE: Gabreski Proposal Faces Hurdles

BYLINE: By JULIA C. MEAD

DATELINE: WESTHAMPTON BEACH 

 BODY:
SUFFOLK COUNTY and the Town of Southampton Town have joined forces to develop a 58-acre commercial and industrial park at the county-owned Gabreski Airport. They predict that the continued presence at the airport of the Air National Guard's 106th Rescue Wing and New York State's proposed homeland security training center would help attract defense-related businesses.
 The problem is, the training center is supposed to be built upstate, and the 106th Rescue Wing has been identified as a possible target of a federal commission charged with identifying military installations that should be closed or consolidated. 
 At a news conference on Monday, Steve Levy, the county executive; Patrick Heaney, Southampton's town supervisor; and a contingent of county officials outlined the reasons they hoped that a section of the 1,400-acre airport, largely neglected by county officials in the past, would be transformed into a thriving economic hub. 
 They said the county and town have resolved longstanding differences over zoning restrictions and potential uses for the land. The master plan the town expects to finish by mid-May calls for 14 lots and about 350,000 square feet of industrial space on the west side of the airport, which is between Sunrise Highway and the Long Island Rail Road tracks. If fully leased, the park could bring 600 to 900 new jobs to Long Island, they said.
 Mr. Levy said that $2.5 million in county money was earmarked for infrastructure improvements, that an additional $3.5 million was available to promote the park to high-tech companies, and that the potential existed for economic and tax incentives to prospective tenants. And, he said, prospective tenants, including Northrop Grumman, have already begun inquiring.
 ''This spot is an economic development jewel,'' Mr. Levy said. ''We consider this an incredible untapped potential.''
 But in his State of the State address in January, Governor Pataki named the Mohawk Valley as the location for the homeland security training center. 
 The airport's neighbors, who have been vehement in their complaints about noise from planes, are leery of further development. Noting that the zoning change would allow higher-density development, Albert Algieri, the president of the East Quogue Association, wondered aloud how residents would benefit.
 ''I find it very hard to believe it won't increase airplane traffic,'' Mr. Algieri said. ''That airport would be a major asset to a plan like this, so why wouldn't the tenants take advantage of it?''
 Sharon Frost, the president of the residents association of Hampton West Estates, across the street from the airport, said she did not see how a homeland security training center or a commercial and industrial park would be compatible with the semi-rural neighborhood.
 ''I understand the importance of creating professional jobs here,'' she said. ''I hate to think my sons have to move away to get decent jobs. But compatible growth in a small community doesn't mean adding 900 new jobs.'' 
 Ken Brown, a spokesman for the state's Office of Homeland Security, said the state had allocated $1 million in federal money to develop a plan for a center where police officers, firefighters and other emergency workers would be trained. ''Currently the state is focused on a centralized training center located in the Mohawk Valley,'' he said.
 Mr. Levy said that two weeks ago he wrote to the governor and to state legislators from Long Island to promote Gabreski as a possible training center site. He acknowledged that a lobbying effort would have been more likely to bear fruit if the governor had not already expressed a preference for the Mohawk Valley. But he said that a mix of businesses with defense contracts, an airport, the 106th Rescue Wing and major transportation routes would create a synergy that would be hard for the state to ignore.
 And in case there's no changing the governor's mind, Mr. Levy said he would push for a Gabreski annex to the training center. 
 Mr. Levy said he was optimistic that the 88-acre Air National Guard base would survive the next round of closures, the sixth since the base closure commission was established in 1988. Hank Beck, the head of the Gabreski Rescue Initiative Partnership, an organization of business and civic leaders, insisted that the 106th could be saved by an intense yearlong lobbying effort directed at the Pentagon, which will submit to the closure commission a list of bases that could be closed. 
 ''If you asked a year ago, I would have said I was cautiously pessimistic,'' said Mr. Beck, who is also the president of the Greater Westhampton Chamber of Commerce. ''That's improved to cautiously optimistic.''
 New York's two senators, along with federal and state legislators and Governor Pataki, want to keep the 106th Rescue Wing on Long Island. Though the Coast Guard has primary responsibility for searches at sea, the 106th, which has 1,275 employees, is the closest search-and-rescue helicopter unit for most of the waters around Long Island. The nearest Coast Guard choppers are in Rhode Island and New Jersey. 
 Mr. Beck said his group had 20,000 signatures on its petitions and a study outlining the base's economic benefit to the community. But the federal Base Realignment and Closure Commission was designed to be immune to lobbying and political pressure. It is expected to make its recommendations to President Bush in September on which bases to close. If the president approves, Congress would then have until November to accept or reject the list, but not to edit it.

HEADLINE: Up for Re-election, And Maybe More

BYLINE: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

 BODY:
SURPRISES were absent from the agenda Thomas R. Suozzi described in his State of the County address on Monday. Not that he needed any. In most circles, fixing Nassau County, fixing Albany and reinventing the concept of suburbia would be considered a full plate.
 Although much of his agenda has been known for months and much of it concerns long-range projects, Mr. Suozzi, the county executive, has a long to-do list in 2005. The announced tasks include lobbying for a cap on the counties' share of Medicaid expenditures, pushing ahead with the Nassau Hub project and laying out what he described in his speech as a ''master plan for the future development of all of Nassau.''
 But there are other items he didn't mention in the speech. Undoubtedly, Mr. Suozzi has set his sights on being re-elected in November, and he invariably tells questioners that he is focused on his job as county executive. But such assurances have not slowed the rumor that he's thinking about a run for governor in 2006. Whether true or not, the rumor is already playing a role in how his actions are perceived, and might be a factor in the 2005 election. 
 In keeping with the scale of his ambitions, he quoted Teddy Roosevelt on Monday on the subject of daring mighty things. But some look at the agenda with skepticism, seeing it as an attempt to create an instant legacy that will propel him to statewide attention and then to the governor's office in 2006. They assert that a ''too much too soon'' agenda cannot be sustained for long.
 ''He's got more balls in the air than a circus juggler,'' said Desmond Ryan, a Republican lobbyist.
 Both the plans and the criticism go back some time. The Fix Albany campaign, opposing the rapid growth of state-mandated expenses and threatening political retaliation against officials who support it, is more than a year old now. Likewise, Mr. Suozzi has been honing his concept of ''new suburbia'' -- maintaining quality of life in a suburban county that has ceased to grow -- since the first year of his term. 
 But much has happened since then. Fix Albany drew its first blood when Mr. Suozzi's hand-picked candidate defeated a Democratic incumbent in a State Assemby primary in Mr. Suozzi's home district last September. Some Democrats were angered by Mr. Suozzi's tactics, but reform became the buzzword in Albany, a development Mr. Suozzi claims is at least partly a result of his pressure.
 In December, Mr. Suozzi became president of New York State County Executives Association, and immediately engaged in backroom negotiations about Medicaid with Governor Pataki and the leaders of the State Senate and Assembly, Joseph Bruno and Sheldon Silver. Though he will not comment on what went on in these discussions, he points out that Medicaid was the centerpiece of the governor's state of the state address in January. Some legislators and other county leaders, on the other hand, say that the struggle over Medicaid has been going on for years.
 For the past few weeks, Mr. Suozzi and other county executives have been holding news conferences and rallies across the state to draw attention to their demand for a cap on the local share of Medicaid. On a snowy Wednesday morning earlier this month, he was standing on a small stage at the civic center in downtown Syracuse, surrounded by county officials from around the state. Mr. Suozzi delivered a speech about the burden of local property taxes on New York citizens, citing a flurry of statistics buttressing his argument that Medicaid programs in other states are fairer to county governments. Flanking the stage were maps of New York State that showed which state legislators had pledged support for a cap on county Medicaid expenses, and which had not.
 At a later news conference in Rockland County, Mr. Suozzi said that legislators who did not support Medicaid reform would be held accountable. Asked if that meant he could be targeting more incumbents, Mr. Suozzi said yes, but emphasized that that was his position, not the position of the county executives' association.
 The fruits of this crusade will be known in the coming months when the Legislature passes a budget. What was clear from Mr. Suozzi's upstate excursions was that Medicaid is already the principal concern of many county governments. Despite his Fix Albany success and his activism as head of the association, Mr. Suozzi may have a hard time being seen as the leader on the issue statewide.
 Joel A. Giambra, the Erie County executive and one who has been mentioned as a possible Republican candidate for governor should Mr. Pataki choose not to run, declared at the Syracuse conference that he had become ''the poster child for Medicaid reform.'' And after the event was over, Mark W. Thomas, the Chautauqua county executive and a former president of the county executives association, disagreed with the characterization that the push for Medicaid reform was led by Mr. Suozzi. 
 ''This year we had all decided as county executives that what we want to do is make the pressure much more public,'' Mr. Thomas said. ''That wasn't Tom's decision. That was our decision as county executives.''
 Mr. Suozzi has been mentioned as a possible candidate for statewide office as far back as the late 1990's, when he was still mayor of Glen Cove. He was said to be mulling over a 1998 run for the United States Senate against Alfonse M. D'Amato, a race that Charles Schumer eventually won. Whatever Mr. Suozzi is thinking now, many are convinced that he will try to move up the political ladder. 
 While Nassau Democrats insist that Mr. Suozzi has not announced any plans, they admit that a run for higher office is not unthinkable.
 ''He would tell you straight out himself that he's ambitious,'' said Lisanne Altmann, the legislator representing Great Neck. ''We need to be sure that if people start moving up or around or whatever the heck happens, that we have enough potential candidates to continue what he's doing,'' she said, adding that she would be interested succeeding Mr. Suozzi as county executive.
 Republicans, for their part, have already folded Mr. Suozzi's purported ambitions into their campaign strategy. In the statement last month announcing his candidacy, Mr. Suozzi's Republican opponent, Greg Peterson, pointedly remarked that he had ''no further personal political agenda.'' 
 Ed Ward, a Republican spokesman, said the Republicans would be bringing up the issue during the 2005 campaign. ''Voters generally evaluate a candidate as to whether they'll deliver on their promises,'' Mr. Ward said. ''If he's not going to be around in 2006 or he's looking to get out soon after the election for county executive, well, that's going to leave a bad taste in the voters' mouths.'' 
 Jay Jacobs, the chairman of the Nassau County Democrats, said Mr. Schumer's overwhelming victory in his recent Senate race amid talk that he would run for governor was proof that voters understand that ''public officials may, at some time in their future, move on to some high elected office that also serves them as the public.''
 Mr. Jacobs suggested that the conjecture actually works to the county's advantage, and that Mr. Suozzi realizes that. 
 ''I think that Tom is really playing it smart by allowing all of this speculation,'' Mr. Jacobs said. ''Is someone more influential if they're under consideration for something higher, or less influential? Would people in high places pay more attention to their needs and requests, or less attention?''
 By far the most daunting obstacle for Mr. Suozzi in a run for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in 2006 would be Eliot Spitzer, who has declared his candidacy, has the backing of most of the state's Democratic leaders and has drawn national media attention during his aggressive tenure as the state attorney general.
 ''Spitzer is presumptively the candidate,'' said Gerald Benjamin, a political scientist and dean of the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at SUNY-New Paltz. Dr. Benjamin said a gubernatorial bid by Mr. Suozzi in 2006 would put his name on the map, but that his real chance would be the 2010 election.
 On the other hand, Dr. Benjamin said, Mr. Spitzer's high-profile prosecutions of Wall Street firms have created a wealthy group of antagonists. ''A credible candidacy by Suozzi is financeable because Spitzer has so many people who don't like him,'' Dr. Benjamin said. ''There's big money that will come to any credible opponent.'' 
 Mr. Spitzer has already raised $7.8 million for his gubernatorial run. Mr. Suozzi has $3.1 million on hand, an impressive amount for a Nassau County executive, but he will have to use at least some of it for his re-election campaign.
 Joseph Mondello, the leader of the Nassau Republicans, has pledged to raise $3 million for the November elections. Gary DelaRaba, the head of the Policeman's Benevolent Association, has also said he will raise $3 million to fight candidates whom he considers weak on law-enforcement issues -- a list that would surely include Mr. Suozzi, who has battled Mr. DelaRaba over cuts to the police budget. 
 A variety of political observers, Republicans as well as Democrats, agree that Mr. Suozzi is in a good position for re-election, given the fact that, with the help of a state-imposed fiscal watchdog agency, his administration has pulled the county government back from the brink of bankruptcy. Even the Republicans have acknowledged the county's newfound fiscal health, though they take issue with the tax increase and service cuts, proposed by Mr. Suozzi and backed by the County Legislature's Democratic majority, that made the turnaround possible. 
 Mr. Suozzi has pointed to several indicators of the county's fiscal health: a quick succession of bond rating increases, consecutive budget surpluses and a declining reliance on ''one shot'' revenues to balance the budget. 
 ''That isn't small potatoes,'' Dr. Benjamin said, adding that it could even be enough of an accomplishment to launch a run for governor. 
 On Monday, Mr. Suozzi described his budget-balancing, and the attempt to go three years without raising property taxes, as ''conservatism in the true sense.'' And that raises another election-year issue: the 9,828 registered Conservatives in Nassau County.
 In addition to touting the conservatism of his fiscal policy, Mr. Suozzi spoke at a Conservative Party conference at the end of January. Despite Mr. Suozzi's party affiliation and despite the fact that Mr. Peterson has had the Conservative nomination for all but one of his races in the past, Democratic, Republican and Conservative party officials all agree that this year Mr. Suozzi has a chance at the nomination.
 ''I think his budget is conservative and I think he has had a fiscal conservative outlook during his tenure as county executive,'' said Roger Bogsted, the head of the Nassau Conservative Party and the county's consumer affairs commissioner. Mr. Bogsted denied that he was influenced by his position in Mr. Suozzi's administration.
 Mr. Suozzi has been introducing big-idea proposals over the past year that go far beyond his original mission of righting the county's fiscal ship. 
 ''New Suburbia is a risky strategy because people will try and misrepresent what I've been saying,'' Mr. Suozzi said in an interview as he was riding up to Rockland County for the Medicaid news conference. ''A lot of my advisers suggested I not talk about New Suburbia and next-generation housing.''
 Next-generation housing is Mr. Suozzi's phrase for what many people call affordable housing, and it's an issue taken up by many business and political leaders who are concerned that rising real estate prices are making most of Long Island unaffordable to the workers who form the backbone of the Island's economy. Talk of these issues, and his embrace of Charles Wang's plan to overhaul the Nassau Coliseum and build a 60-story tower next door, have already invited charges that Mr. Suozzi has plans to urbanize Nassau County and bring in low-income housing.
 ''All of these things are designed to boost Tom Suozzi's name recognition and approval and perhaps to use that as leverage to go on from the county executive's office,'' said Bradford O'Hearn, a Democratic consultant.
 Mr. Suozzi says that these ideas are primarily about one thing: taxes. He draws a direct line between the need for Medicaid reform and the growth of local property taxes. He describes New Suburbia as a way to increase tax revenues. 
 In fact, Mr. Suozzi said he was considering holding community forums about tax issues sometime in the future. Already he has been touring the county with his New Suburbia concept, holding forums in 35 ''economic development zones'' charted by his administration.
 A week after the trip to Syracuse, Mr. Suozzi was standing in the auditorium of the New Hyde Park Road School for the 31st forum. New Hyde Park is a traditionally Republican stronghold, one of the few areas in the county that he did not carry in 2001. Some in the crowd seemed hostile to the New Suburbia idea. Others had different priorities; when he opened the floor to discussion, the popular subjects were street sweeping and garbage collection. But everyone agreed in the end, by a show of hands, that the forum had been a good idea.
 Joseph Schilly, a retired Port Authority supervisor who lives in New Hyde Park, said he has yet to make up his mind about Mr. Suozzi but voted for him in 2001 because he was unhappy about the county's direction under the Republican, Thomas S. Gulotta. 
 Before the forum began, Mr. Schilly said the little that he knew about this New Suburbia idea bothered him. When it was over, he said Mr. Suozzi's presentation made some sense, but he still needed some convincing.
 ''We do need things that will enhance our revenue, it's true,'' Mr. Schilly said. ''I just don't see where the revitalization of my little village is going to do that.''
 But he complimented Mr. Suozzi for his persuasiveness. ''If I had six new pairs of good shoes and he was a shoe salesman, I think he could sell me another pair,'' Mr. Schilly said, laughing. ''And I'm very hard on salesmen.''

SECTION: Section 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk; LIVING IN/Pelham Bay, the Bronx; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1364 words

HEADLINE: Within Commuting Distance of Everywhere Else

BYLINE: By CLAIRE WILSON

 BODY:
WHEN John and Deirdre Hartz were married last summer and wanted a place that was bigger than Mr. Hartz's $650-a-month rental in Queens, there were two things on their wish list. First, that the new apartment be in the Bronx where Ms. Hartz was a teaching fellow. Second, that it be on the No. 6 subway line so Mr. Hartz would have an easy commute to his public relations job in Manhattan. 
 Thinking there might be a nice neighborhood at the end of the No. 6 line like those they knew at the end of the Nos. 1 and 9 lines (Riverdale), and the N and the W lines (Astoria), Ms. Hartz took a ride one Wednesday afternoon to check it out. 
 ''She walked all around the neighborhood, then called me from Pelham Bay Park and said, 'This looks beautiful; we should look for a place here,''' Mr. Hartz recalled. 
 Within weeks, they signed on a spacious $850-a-month one-bedroom apartment in a three-story brick building in Pelham Bay, about a one-minute walk from the Buhre Avenue subway station. The noise from passing trains was a bit unsettling at first, but they were quickly distracted by the convenience to both their jobs and to the park, where the couple trained together for last fall's New York City Marathon and where they jog or ride bicycles on weekends. 
 ''In the summer, I run all the way to Orchard Beach, take a swim in Long Island Sound and run back,'' Mr. Hartz said. It takes him about an hour.
 The rush-hour commute to Manhattan likewise takes about an hour, either by an express bus that costs $5 one-way or by subway from the Pelham Bay Park subway stop, which is also a major local bus hub. This proximity to mass transit as well as to a network of major roadways is a big part of the appeal of the enclave. 
 ''You can go anywhere from here,'' said Dorothy DeMarco, a sales agent and co-owner of Town and Country Homes and Properties. ''Manhattan is 15 minutes by car, Connecticut is 15 minutes and Route 95 to Westchester is accessible.'' 
 The character of the neighborhood has changed little in 35 years, according to many longtime residents who have been in the same spot for decades. Detached and semiattached houses in a broad range of ages and styles on skinny lots line wide streets that are shaded with mature trees. The mix also includes some low-rise apartment buildings and a handful of co-ops and condos. Two- and three-family homes are prevalent and increasing in number as older houses, particularly single-family detached ones, are knocked down to make way for attached and semiattached units with rental incomes. 
 New construction has aggravated an already serious parking problem in the area, and prompted local officials to call for the kind of down-zoning slowly taking effect in Throgs Neck as well as in parts of Queens and Staten Island. According to James Vacca, district manager for Community Board 10, who is running for the City Council seat to be vacated this year by Councilwoman Madeline Provenzano, proposed regulations would help cap population density and require more off-street parking. 
 ''We have higher density housing than we would like and we do not have sufficient parking,'' said Mr. Vacca, who grew up in Pelham Bay. 
 The motto for Pelham Bay could well be, ''Build it and they will come'' -- and buy it. Brokers maintain waiting lists of potential buyers and nothing stays on the market very long, according to Phyllis Basilone, an associate broker with Prudential Kafcos Realty. 
 ''If something is priced right, it sells immediately,'' Ms. Basilone said. When an offer she got fell through recently on a $480,000 five-bedroom two-family detached house, she resold it within days and had a back-up offer to boot, she said. 
 Currently, the prices on older two-families run between $425,000 and $490,000, while new two-families with amenities like fireplaces, several baths, laundry rooms and off-street parking can range from $625,000 to $700,000. Two older, single-family-detached homes now on the market include a 1,200-square-foot, three-bedroom, one-and-a-half bath side hallway colonial for $379,000, and a 1,300-square foot, three-bedroom, one-and-a-half bath colonial for $389,000.
 High demand fueled by low mortgage rates and attractive 8- and 15-year tax abatements on new construction have helped double the price of Pelham Bay houses in the last five or six years, according to George Bookis, an owner of Aztec Realty. Taxes that are much lower than in Westchester have buyers returning south. 
 New condominiums in the area include a 21-unit, seven-story building on Parkview Avenue. One-bedroom, one-bath units sold for $175,000 to $205,000, while two-bedroom, one-bath units sold for $175,000 to $305,000. 
 Area co-ops are less expensive, with one-bedroom units ranging from $85,000 to $92,000 and two-bedroom units from $115,000 to $125,000, according to Bill Rizopoulos, a broker with Pel-Bay Realty, who said most buyers for co-ops and condos tend to come from the Bronx and want to stay in the borough. 
 The majority of rental units are in two- and three-family homes, and start at $850 for a one-bedroom, while a studio would be slightly less. Two-bedrooms run about $1,200 per month, and three-bedrooms are about $1,500 per month. 
 Area families have their choice of schools, which include Public School 14 on Bruckner Boulevard, which teaches kindergarten through Grade 5 and where among fourth-grade students 79.3 percent performed at or above grade level in math, and 49.5 per cent performed at or above grade level in English. Of fourth graders at Public School 71, 72 percent performed at or above grade level in math and 56.3 percent performed at or above grade level in English. 
 Most Pelham Bay children move on to attend Intermediate School 192 on Hollywood Avenue, which teaches Grades 6 to 9. Of all eighth-grade students, 27.7 percent performed at or above grade level in math and 28.1 percent scored at or above grade level in English. Then it's on to Herbert H. Lehman High School, on East Tremont Avenue, where for those students taking the 2003 SAT reasoning test, the average score was 451 in math compared with a statewide average of 510; and 431 on the verbal test, compared with 496 statewide. 
 Roman Catholic schools in the area all teach prekindergarten through grade 8. They include St. Benedict's School on Edison Avenue, Our Lady of the Assumption School on Parkview Avenue, and St. Theresa School on St. Theresa Avenue. 
 At 2,764 acres, Pelham Bay Park is three times the size of Central Park and a virtual paradise for joggers, dog walkers, bike riders and sunbathers. The park also has nine miles of shoreline, part of which includes Orchard Beach. 
 It's the many restaurants in his new neighborhood that do it for Marcos Torres, an investment banker who grew up in Harlem and last year bought a new two-family house in Pelham Bay with fireplaces, balconies and skylights for about $680,000. His favorite brunch spot is the Cross Town Diner on Interstate 95, but for dinner it is Patricia's Pizza and Pasta II on East Tremont Avenue. 
 ''It's such good stuff I feel like I've been lying in the sun for five hours getting a full body massage,'' Mr. Torres said. 
 A newly spiffed up Key Food is the supermarket of choice in Pelham Bay to which the closest major shopping areas are Bay Plaza and the Mall at Bay Plaza on Bartow Avenue, a few miles away. But stores there like Old Navy, J.C. Penney, and Kmart offer little to rival the family-owned businesses along Crosby and Westchester Avenues, where merchants and waiters know their customers by name. 
 Business has never been better at the Pelham Bake Shop & Cafe, where Maria Fumaso, who owns the shop with her husband, Victor, is too busy to think much about the economics of the real estate that surrounds her. 
 ''We have four banks, three Catholic churches and two butchers here, and where there are four banks, there's money,'' she said. ''But real estate around here? That's crazy.''

What Not to Miss
 They may leave the Bronx, but customers always come back to the Pelham Bay Bake Shop and Cafe to stock up on holiday specialties or, year-round, for an espresso and a flaky sfogliatelle, or a creamy cannoli, a bargain at $1.75.
