HEADLINE: 4th and Goal

BYLINE: By JOSH BENSON

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
ASK Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey about the surprisingly swift disintegration of the state's negotiations with the New York Giants over a new football stadium in the Meadowlands, and he expresses cautious optimism.
 ''I'm not getting upset about it,'' the governor said in an interview last week. ''At the end of the day, I think we do a deal.'' 
 But mention Xanadu --a five million-square-foot retail, entertainment, hotel and office complex featuring a chocolate waterfall, artificial ski slope and paintball range -- which has butted up against the Giants' plans, and Mr. Codey is considerably less sanguine. 
 ''It's a tough one for me because the Giants have the right to block it,'' said Mr. Codey, who has made it a priority to reach a deal with the Giants, and yet has stated his support for Xanadu. ''And with all due respect to the sports authority,'' he said, referring to the state agency that oversees the Meadowlands Sports Complex, ''that should have been dealt with ahead of time. I was handed a bad deck there.''
 Sensing that he still had not adequately explained the state's handling of Xanadu -- a $1.3 billion complex being developed by the Mills Corporation and Mack-Cali Realty -- he quickly added, ''I would have preferred if the sports authority had gotten signoff from teams before they were off on this adventure, and it can be called an adventure.''
 If nothing else, Mr. Codey's comment was illustrative of how the Xanadu project has become a seemingly unstoppable force, even as it complicates the state's position in the Meadowlands and threatens to turn it into a quagmire of conflicting promises, visions and interests. Indeed, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority gave Xanadu final approval last week.
 Ever since the Giants declared negotiations at a standstill little more than a week ago, the situation has been characterized by wild speculation and every scenario from the Giants moving to a stadium in Manhattan to what turned out to be an offhand joke -- the New York Jets buying Giants stadium. 
 While the Giants have done their menacing best to look sincere about leaving, sports authority officials have signaled their indifference by feeding the media a steady diet of alternate plans involving the Jets. Such possibilities are as likely to be bargaining ploys as serious plans.
 At the moment, the state is awaiting a response from the Giants to a request filed in court to determine the precise nature of its obligation to upgrade the stadium to ''state of the art.'' But if the financing disputes are a simple matter of negotiation and arbitration, the Xanadu question promises to be more intractable.
 According to Giants officials, they were set to come to an agreement with the state, leaving their concerns about the congesting effects of a huge shopping and entertainment complex on game days to a sort of final negotiation with the developers of Xanadu. But to hear them tell it, the talks imploded when the state suddenly demanded that the Giants sign off on Xanadu without addressing concerns that the team says violates the terms of the lease.
 ''There's no way in hell we're going to sign off on Xanadu before we come to agreement with them on how we coexist, especially on the day of the game,'' said Pat Hanlon, a spokesman for the Giants. ''We're not going to invest in a new stadium and hope that with Xanadu and Giants Stadium in operation on game day, that somehow it all works out. It's a known fact that's its already difficult enough to get in and out of this facility.''
 Mr. Hanlon also said he was convinced that there was more than logistical considerations and cold hard logic behind the state's position on Xanadu. ''My sense is that politics and money play a big part in it,'' he insisted.
 With the backing of some of the most powerful political figures in the state dating to the administration of acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco and carrying on through Gov. James E. McGreevey's abbreviated tenure, the project's momentum has been inexorable, whether faced with opposition from environmental groups, National Football League franchises or even the odd elected official who expressed reservation about the complex.
 There are, of course, many proponents of the project who have pointed to its economic potential. Mr. McGreevey earned wide public praise when he appointed George Zoffinger to head the sports authority with a mandate of weaning the agency from public subsidies and increasing the profitability of the Meadowlands. 
 Mr. Zoffinger quickly became a firm backer of Xanadu, signaling an end to the era when the state -- desperate for a sports identity -- bent over backward to accommodate sports teams instead of seeking the best economic deal for itself.
 But the plan quickly became a magnet for controversy as cost estimates rose, environmental complications emerged and questions multiplied over the bidding process. Then last year, the resident teams of the Meadowlands began doing their best to pour gasoline on the fire by threatening to sue the state or even leave if Xanadu went ahead as planned.
 Mr. Codey -- a sports fan who has no intention of watching idly as New Jersey loses its football, basketball and hockey franchises -- came into office last November with the intention of ordering a comprehensive review of the state's plans for Xanadu. He said at the time: ''If we don't do anything, what does the place become? Is it just a dying football stadium, a racetrack and a place for shopping? I don't think that's right.''
 But soon after making those and other similar comments, Mr. Codey released an uncharacteristically formal-sounding statement of his support for the project, bringing his vision suddenly into line with that of the project's longtime supporters.
 Critics have consistently claimed that state officials were under enormous political pressure to back Xanadu. ''There are more inside political deals, connections and money going on with Xanadu than probably with any other project in New Jersey,'' said Jeff Tittel, president of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club and a longtime opponent of the project. ''Xanadu is the palace of pay to play.'' 
 Mr. Zoffinger, Xanadu's most tireless public proponent, insisted last week that the forces driving the project were purely economic. ''I re-emphasize to everyone every day that when this Xanadu project is completed it will be an engine that drives the economy of northern New Jersey,'' he said in a telephone interview. ''This is not about politics.''
 He said that he was hopeful that Xanadu could co-exist with one or even two professional football franchises. But if he had to choose -- football or paintball -- he left little doubt where his allegiance lay. 
 ''I guess my attitude is that it's so difficult to get anything done in New Jersey nowadays that when you have an opportunity to build something that is going to provide the kind of job growth and economic development that this project will bring to New Jersey, you've got to do everything you can to put your head down and get it done.''

HEADLINE: How Open Is Open Space?

BYLINE: By TERRY GOLWAY

DATELINE: HOBOKEN 

 BODY:
THERE is an unsightly pile of rubble in a vacant lot along Monroe Street in the northwest corner of this waterfront city. Developers say that one day the rubble will give way to a beautiful swimming pool and a two-story community center.
 Of course, that is not the only construction the developers have in mind along this bleak stretch of old, industrial Hoboken. The swimming pool and community center are part of a much larger project, one that would see the construction of a 12-story, 125-unit apartment building adjacent to the Ninth Street Light Rail station.
 The developers, Tarragon Realty Investors Inc. and the URSA Development Group L.L.C., have built several other residential projects in the western part of this densely packed city. 
 Now, with the support of Mayor David Roberts, they are looking to transform an 11-acre industrial site into a high-rise residential development that will include more than five acres of open space for the public. City law requires builders to set aside 10 percent of a tract as open space, and the open space to be set aside for the Monroe Street project will amount to nearly half the property. 
 Still, some Hoboken residents are crying foul, saying that the entire site ought to be preserved as open space and municipal parkland in a city whose 38,000 residents do not have enough parks and playgrounds. Critics used the same argument against another high-rise proposal in the western part of the city, but the City Council approved that 11-story, 113-unit residential building on Jackson Street earlier this month.
 While the dispute is a common tale of developers confronted by residents, it also has policy implications in a state where public officials are trying to combat sprawl by making urban redevelopment more attractive. 
 The site -- dominated by a trucking company terminal and old warehouses surrounded by parking lots pitted with puddles -- would seem ripe for redevelopment. In fact, both William S. Friedman, the chief executive of Tarragon, and Fred M. Bado, director of community development for Hoboken, cited the proposal as an example of anti-sprawl, smart-growth development. 
 ''This is a site that is near public transportation and shopping, in an old industrial area,'' Mr. Friedman said. ''It corresponds to all the ideas behind smart growth.''
 But residents of the state's crowded cities may be as reluctant to part with potential open space as suburbanites weary of strip malls and townhouse construction.
 ''Our elected officials just don't get it,'' said Ron Hines, executive director of Fund for a Better Waterfront, a nonprofit advocacy organization based in Hoboken. ''This is not something that resulted from thoughtful planning. This is a developer-driven proposal.'' 
 The proposal has also drawn criticism from residents of Jersey City and Union City, who live atop the Palisades overlooking Hoboken. They contend the proposed building will block their views and strain the resources of Hudson County. 
 ''From my point of view, the project will affect our line of sight to New York City, and would affect our quality of life in general,'' said Martin McBride, who lives in the Doric, a high-rise apartment building atop the Palisades in Union City.
 Opponents braved bone-chilling temperatures and wind gusts on the steps of Hoboken City Hall about two weeks ago to demonstrate against the proposal, which would require a zoning variance to allow high-rise construction. The developers have agreed to pay the city $80,000 to finance a study that will determine whether the tract should be included in Hoboken's redevelopment zone. If the study finds that site should be redeveloped, the developers could be granted a variance to build higher than the current limit of four stories.
 Mr. Hines and other critics are not mollified by the prospect of a community center, swimming pool and promises of accessible park and recreation areas akin to a smaller version of Battery Park City. 
 ''That is not how you design a public park,'' he said. ''We know this is not going to work.''
 But Mr. Bado, the Hoboken development official, insisted that critics who believe the entire tract should be dedicated as open space ''are not being realistic.'' He estimated that the cost of purchasing the land and then transforming it into usable open space could run as much as $100 million.
 The developers point out that about half the tract will be open to the public, and they hold out visions of tree-lined walkways and bicycle paths leading to playgrounds, a dog run and other passive recreational facilities, like park benches. In addition, the nearly 27,000-square-foot community center would house dance and art studios, a gymnasium, exercise rooms and a space for social functions. A 25-yard pool and a smaller children's pool would be built adjacent to the community center.
 Michael Sciarra, a principal in URSA Development, said the pools and community center ''will make a qualitative difference in the lives of Hoboken residents.''
 Nonetheless, many residents who do not live in Hoboken think the project will make a difference in their lives, too, but not in the positive way Mr. Sciarra suggested.
 ''The views we enjoy from the parks in Jersey City Heights should be valued and considered a Hudson County resource,'' said Moyna McCarty, a Jersey City resident who believes the development will spoil those views. 
 Ms. McCarty criticized Hoboken officials for not considering the effect of the proposed development on neighboring communities and on the Palisades. And she is concerned about the building boom under way along the Hoboken stretch of the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail Line. 
 ''A lot of people think the light rail is a great thing, but it is also an attraction for development,'' she said.
 Becky Hoffman, who is also a Jersey City resident and president of a civic group called the Hudson County Alliance, complained that the development would ''wall up the Palisades'' and ''create a precedent for additional high-rise buildings'' that will block views from the communities above Hoboken. 
 As Ms. Hoffman put it, ''This is a natural resource, but Hoboken continues to present high-rise projects at the base of the Palisades.''
 It has been hard for supporters of the development not to notice the number of non-Hoboken residents weighing in on a local land-use issue. 
 ''Their objective isn't about creating open space,'' Mr. Bado said. ''Their objective is to stop development. That's why residents from Jersey City and Union City are coming down here. They feel that development in Hoboken will block their views, so they don't want development.''
 The land-use issue also promises to become a political issue this year, with a critic of the development, Councilwoman Carol Marsh, opposing the re-election of Mayor Roberts in May. Ms. Marsh was one of two members of the City Council who voted against a plan to allow Tarragon/URSA to finance the redevelopment study. (The motion passed, 6-2.) And the development's opponents have noted that URSA contributed more than $35,000 to Mayor Roberts' campaign since 2001.
 For his part, the mayor has dismissed the suggestion that the developer's contributions have played a role in the redevelopment plan. And Mr. Bado said that in his 30 years ''on the public side of development, I've never made a deal.''
 ''We just feel this is the way to go,'' Mr. Bado said. ''The city has to be innovative in creating open space. That's why we looked at this area.''

HEADLINE: Despite Property Tax Furor, Little Is Likely to Be Done

BYLINE: By David Kocieniewski. 
David Kocieniewski is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
With the possible exceptions of traffic jams and crooked politicians, nothing gets New Jerseyeans as riled as property taxes.
 Homeowners here pay the highest taxes in the nation, and after a decade of escalating complaints, state residents have been rewarded with escalating property taxes. Now, as spiraling real estate prices drive property taxes even higher, the furor has set off a swirl of activity by elected officials.
 Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey's proposal to roll back the property tax rebate has touched off a nasty battle with fellow Democrats -- especially Assembly members, who fear that voters will punish them if the rebates are eliminated. 
 A bill to convene a constitutional convention on property taxes is inching through the Legislature. And the Republican contenders for governor are lobbing the issue like a dirty bomb at each other and at Jon Corzine, the Democratic candidate.
 Yet despite all those political rumblings, there are plenty of reasons for voters to suspect that little will be done. And the most important reason is the voters themselves.
 New Jersey's property taxes, more than $17 billion last year, are high because they pay for 75 percent of the cost of operating the state's bureaucracy-laden schools and local governments. To make any meaningful rollback, the state can either cut costs, raise taxes or find another revenue source. While those options might sound simple in a campaign, trying to enact them can be difficult and politically perilous.
 One proposal occasionally floated is to increase the sales tax from its current 6 percent (and begin taxing a litany of exempt items -- from luxury boxes at stadiums to food and clothing) and use that revenue to relieve property taxes by providing more school and local aid. 
 Well, a two-cent increase in the sales tax would raise slightly more than $2 billion a year, about enough to cover the property tax increases in the past two years. Many experts contend that sales taxes are regressive, unfairly hitting poor and middle-income families. 
 Merchants argue that a higher sales tax will punish retail businesses, especially shops near the state border, which derive considerable sales from out-of-state-residents. If sales fell significantly, so would sales tax collections, meaning that the state might find itself cutting local aid, pushing property taxes up again.
 An increase in the income tax is another option. But the state already increased the rates on wealthy, and some economists worry that another rise could hurt the state's competitive position and drive away businesses and residents. Given the uprising when Gov. James Florio increased taxes in 1990, legislators are understandably squeamish.
 The prospect of making substantial spending cuts is even riskier. Every elected official likes to promise fiscal restraint and, sometimes, they do find ways to economize. Mr. Codey's budget proposal for next year trims spending by 2 percent. Leonard Lance, the Senate minority leader, has advocated challenging the court order that forces New Jersey to finance low-income schools at the same level as the state's wealthiest districts. That move could save $500 million a year by some estimates, but would face opposition in the Legislature and might be struck down by the State Supreme Court.
 The most obvious way to make substantial savings would be to consolidate the state's hodgepodge of local governments. New Jersey has 566 municipal governments and 611 school districts, some of which don't even operate schools. Each entity has to pay for secretarial costs and office space, computers and paper clips. Some of Mr. Codey's top economic advisers say that consolidation could save $2 billion a year -- allowing property tax deductions of 10 percent or more.
 Of course, one man's bureaucracy is another's income. Streamlining local governments and school boards would cost some public employees their livelihoods and strip hundreds of local politicos of their fiefs. Even if the convention were to embrace such a plan, the battle to implement it would resemble a civil war.
 ''Consolidation always sounds like a good idea -- as long as it only involves someone else's school or community,'' said Ernest C. Reock Jr., a professor emeritus at Rutgers University, and a member of the group that drew up a plan for a convention.
 Some policy analysts are hopeful that the problem is reaching critical mass. Jon Shure, who worked in the Florio administration and now heads a liberal research organization, says voters are tired of the problem and may accept a profound change.
 Inside the State House, most elected officials and political operatives are doubtful. Legislators say the bill for a convention stands a good chance in the Assembly -- providing Democrats cover during the campaign -- but is likely to die in the Senate. The gubernatorial candidates will keep clubbing each other with the issue and, whoever is elected will have to gauge which is more perilous: doing nothing or facing an uprising by doing something drastic.
 But barring any political sea change, homeowners are likely to face the thing they detest but are reluctant to change: higher property taxes.


GRAPHIC: Photo: David Kocieniewski

SUBJECT: PROPERTY TAX (91%); POLITICS (90%); US DEMOCRATIC PARTY (90%); TAXES & TAXATION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); TAX INCREASES (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); SALES TAX (89%); TAX LAW (89%); RETAILERS (86%); REAL ESTATE (78%); REAL ESTATE VALUATIONS (78%); MIDDLE INCOME PERSONS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (78%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (78%); BUDGETS (78%); GOVERNORS (77%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (77%); SALES FIGURES (76%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (76%); NEW ISSUES (74%); TAX RELIEF (73%); BUDGET PROPOSALS (71%); BUDGET PLANNING & MANAGEMENT (71%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (70%); RETAIL SALES (69%); BOMBS & EXPLOSIVE DEVICES (68%); FAMILY (61%); STADIUMS & ARENAS (50%) Terms not available from NYTimes

PERSON: LEONARD LANCE (58%); JON CORZINE (58%)

GEOGRAPHIC: TRENTON, NJ, USA (79%) NEW JERSEY, USA (92%) UNITED STATES (92%)

LOAD-DATE: March 20, 2005
